For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: photGNObs
parameter.description: Number of observations contributing to G photometry
parameter.detailed-description: Number of observations that contributed to the G mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photGMeanFlux
parameter.detailed-description: Mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photGMeanFluxError
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photGMeanMag
parameter.detailed-description: Mean magnitude in the G band. This is computed from the G-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpNObs
parameter.description: Number of observations contributing to BP photometry
parameter.detailed-description: Number of observations that contributed to the integrated BP mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpMeanFlux
parameter.detailed-description: Mean flux in the integrated BP band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpMeanFluxError
parameter.description: Error on the integrated BP mean flux
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the mean flux in the integrated BP band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpMeanMag
parameter.detailed-description:
Mean magnitude in the integrated BP band. This is computed from the BP-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale.
This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photRpNObs
parameter.description: Number of observations contributing to RP photometry
parameter.detailed-description: Number of observations that contributed to the integrated RP mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photRpMeanFlux
parameter.detailed-description: Mean flux in the integrated RP band.

parameter.name: photRpMeanFluxError
parameter.description: Error on the integrated RP mean flux
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the mean flux in the integrated RP band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photRpMeanMag
parameter.detailed-description:
Mean magnitude in the integrated RP band. This is computed from the RP-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale.
This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: radialVelocity
parameter.detailed-description: Radial Velocity of the object: the radial velocity provided will be the combination of the RV measurements at all epochs (covered by R1). Specifically, it is the spectroscopic radial velocity in the solar baricentric reference frame.

parameter.name: radialVelocityError
parameter.description: Standard error of the Radial Velocity
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{v_r}$ of Radial Velocity of the object at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: radialVelocityConstancyProbability
parameter.description: probability of constancy of radial velocity

parameter.name: photVariableFlag

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Core/Cepheid
table.description: This table describes the identified Cepheids. The processed Gaia time series contain all observations with CU7-reject flag=0, as found in PhotVariableTimeSeriesGfov table.

parameter.name: cepheidTypeClassification
parameter.description: Cepheid type classification for the target star: cepheidTypeClassification[]= [ProbToBeDcep,ProbToBeT2Cep, ProbToBeACep] (Null if absent)

parameter.name: cepheidType2SubClassification
parameter.description: Type2 Cepheid subclassification for the target star: cepheidType2SubClassification[]=[ProbToBeBlHer, ProbToBeWVir, ProbToBeRvTau] (Null if absent)

parameter.name: cepheidModeClassification
parameter.description: Cepheid mode classification for the target star: cepheidModeClassification[]=[ProbToBeFoundamental, ProbToBeFirstOvertone, ProbToBeSecondOvertone] (Null if absent)

parameter.name: cepheidTypeBestClassification
parameter.description: Best type classification estimate out of: {"DCEP", "T2CEP", "ACEP"} (Null if absent)

parameter.name: cepheidType2BestSubClassification
parameter.description: Best type2 subclassification estimate out of: {"BL_HER", "W_VIR","RV_TAU"} (Null if absent)

parameter.name: cepheidModeBestClassification
parameter.description: Best mode classification estimate out of: {"FUNDAMENTAL", "FIRST_OVERTONE","SECOND_OVERTONE"} (Null if absent)]

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: PF
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the fundamental pulsation mode (for multi mode pulsators) in the G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: PF: for pulsators with one secondary periodicity this parameter is filled with the period corresponding to the longer periodicity. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The parameter type is double and its value ranges from 0.1 to hundreds of days depending on the variable star type.

parameter.name: PFError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the PF period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
PFerror: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it PF} parameter.
The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P1O
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the first overtone pulsation mode (for multi mode pulsators) in the G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P1O: for pulsators with one secondary periodicity this parameter is filled with the period corresponding to the shorter periodicity. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P1OError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the P1O period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P1OError: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it P1O} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P2O
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the second overtone pulsation mode (for multi mode pulsators) in the G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P2O: for multimode pulsators with three periodicities this parameter is filled with the period corresponding to third and shorter periodicity, already called {\it p2} (see above), whereas P1O and PF are the intermediate, and the longer periodicities, respectively. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time-series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P2OError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the P2O period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P2OError: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it P2O} parameter, already called {\it p3Error} (see above). The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time-series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p1
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the maximum power peak in the periodogram of G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the period of the maximum power peak in the frequencygram obtained from the modeling of the time series. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the G-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double and its value ranges from 0.1 to hundreds of days depending on the variable star type.

parameter.name: p1Error
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the p1 period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it p1} parameter. Its value is derived with Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the period is derived from the non linear modeling with a truncated Fourier series of the light curve. The mean of all the periods found and its standard deviation are then computed, and the latter value is kept as value to fill the {\it periodError} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p2
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the second maximum power peak in the periodogram of G band time series (for multi-mode pulsators) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the second periodicity for variable stars. The value is obtained modeling the time series using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p2Error
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the p2 period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it p2} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the p2 is computed. The mean of all the periods and its standard deviation are then computed, and the latter value is kept as value to fill the {\it p2Error} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p3
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the third maximum power peak in the periodogram of G band time series (for multi-mode pulsators) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the third periodicity value for variable stars. The value is obtained modeling the time series using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p3Error
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the p3 period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it p3} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the p3 is computed. The mean of all the periods found and its standard deviation are then computed, and the latter value is kept to fill the {\it p3Error} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: epochG
parameter.description: Epoch of the maximum of the light curve in the G band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
this parameter is filled with the epoch of maximum light epoch for the Gaia G band. It corresponds to the Baricentric Julian day (BJD) of the maximum value of the light curve model which is closer to the BJD of the first observations -3$\times$(Period of the variable). The type of this parameter is double.
The mentioned BJD is offset by the Gaia default of JD 2455197.5 (= J2010.0).

parameter.name: epochBp
parameter.description: Epoch of the maximum of the light curve in the BP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
this parameter is filled with the epoch of maximum light epoch for the Gaia integrated BP band. It corresponds to the Baricentric Julian day (BJD) of the maximum value of the light curve model which is closer to the BJD of the first observations -3$\times$(Period of the variable). The type of this parameter is double.
The mentioned BJD is offset by the Gaia default of JD 2455197.5 (= J2010.0).

parameter.name: epochRp
parameter.description: Epoch of the maximum of the light curve in the RP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
this parameter is filled with the epoch of maximum light epoch for the Gaia integrated RP band. It corresponds to the Baricentric Julian day (BJD) of the maximum value of the light curve model which is closer to the BJD of the first observations -3$\times$(Period of the variable). The type of this parameter is double.
The mentioned BJD is offset by the Gaia default of JD 2455197.5 (= J2010.0).

parameter.name: epochGError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the epoch parameter epochG (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it epochG} parameter. Its value is three times the error on the period. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: epochBpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the epoch parameter epochBp (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it epochBp} parameter. Its value is three times the error on the period. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: epochRpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the epoch parameter epochRp (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it epochRp} parameter. Its value is three times the error on the period. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageG
parameter.description: intensity-averaged magnitude in the G band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the intensity-averaged magnitude in the $G$-band. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageGError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on intAverageG parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with uncertainty value of the {\it intAverageG} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageBp
parameter.description: intensity-averaged magnitude in the BP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the intensity-averaged magnitude in the $G_{BP}$-band. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageBpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on intAverageBp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with uncertainty value of the {\it intAverageBp} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageRp
parameter.description: intensity-averaged magnitude in the RP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the intensity-averaged magnitude in the $G_{RP}$-band. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageRpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on intAverageRp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with uncertainty value of the {\it intAverageRp} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: averageRvError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on averageRv parameter (0 if absent)

parameter.name: peakToPeakG
parameter.description: Peak-to-peak amplitude of the G band light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the peak-to-peak amplitude value of the $G$ band light curve. The peak-to-peak amplitude is calculated as the (maximum) - (minimum) of the folded modeled light curve in the $G$ band. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $G$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakGError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the peakToPeakG parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it peakToPeakG} parameter. The uncertainty is computed as the $\sqrt{2} error(Zp)$, where $Zp$ is the zero point obtained by the non linear fourier modeling of the light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakBp
parameter.description: Peak-to-peak amplitude of the BP band light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the peak-to-peak amplitude value value of the $BP$ light curve. The peak-to-peak amplitude is calculated as the (maximum) - (minimum) of the folded modeled light curve in the $BP$ band. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $BP$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakBpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the peakToPeakBp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it peakToPeakBp} parameter. The uncertainty is computed as the $\sqrt{2} error(Zp)$, where $Zp$ is the zero point obtained by the non linear fourier modeling of the light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakRp
parameter.description: Peak-to-peak amplitude of the RP band light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the peak-to-peak amplitude value. The peak-to-peak amplitude is calculated as the (maximum) - (minimum) of the folded modeled light curve in the $RP$ band. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $RP$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakRpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the peakToPeakRp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it peakToPeakRp} parameter. The uncertainty is computed as the $\sqrt{2} error(Zp)$, where $Zp$ is the zero point obtained by the non linear fourier modeling of the light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: metallicity
parameter.description: Metallicity of the star from the Fourier parameters of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: metallicity: this parameter is filled with the [Fe/H] metallicity derived for the source from the Fourier parameters of the G-band light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: metallicityError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the metallicity parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: metallicityError: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it metallicity} derived from the Fourier parameters of the G-band light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: numHarmonicsForP1
parameter.description: Number of harmonics used to model P1 of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the number of harmonics used to model P1 of the light curve. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. If the target star is a multi-mode pulsator, the previous sum is extended to all existing periodicities. The parameter type is an integer and refers to the $G$-band light curve analysis.

parameter.name: numHarmonicsForP2
parameter.description: Number of harmonics used to model P2 of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the number of harmonics used to model P2 of the light curve. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. If the target star is a multi-mode pulsator, the previous sum is extended to all existing periodicities. The parameter type is an integer and refers to the $G$-band light curve analysis.

parameter.name: numHarmonicsForP3
parameter.description: Number of harmonics used to model P3 of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the number of harmonics used to model P3 of the light curve. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. If the target star is a multi-mode pulsator, the previous sum is extended to all existing periodicities. The parameter type is an integer and refers to the $G$-band light curve analysis.

parameter.name: r11G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter r21G: A2/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $R_{21} = A_2/A_1$. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $R_{i1}$ is defined as, $A_{i}/A_{1}$ where $A_{i}$ is the amplitude of the {\it i}th harmonic and $A_{1}$ is the amplitude of the foundamental harmonic of the truncated Fourier series defined above. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: r31G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter r31G: A3/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $R_{31} = A_3/A_1$. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $R_{i1}$ is defined as, $A_{i}/A_{1}$ where $A_{i}$ is the amplitude of the {\it i}th harmonic and $A_{1}$ is the amplitude of the foundamental harmonic of the truncated Fourier series defined above. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: r21GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the r21G parameter: A2/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value on the {\it r11G} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the ri1 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviations are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value is derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: r31GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the r31G parameter: A3/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value on the {\it r31G} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the ri1 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviations are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value is derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi21G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter phi21G: phi2 − 2*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $\phi_{21}$: $\phi_2 - 2\phi_1$ value. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max} t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $G$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $\phi_{i1}$ is defined as, $\phi_{i}- i \times \phi_{1}$. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi31G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter phi31G: phi3 − 3*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $\phi_{31}$: $\phi_3 - 3\phi_1$ value. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max} t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $G$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $\phi_{i1}$ is defined as, $\phi_{i}- i \times \phi_{1}$. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi21GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the phi21G parameter: phi2 − 2*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it phi21G}: $\phi_2 - 2\phi_1$ parameter. Its value derives from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the phi21 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviation are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi31GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the phi31G parameter: phi3 − 3*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it phi31G}: $\phi_3 - 3\phi_1$ parameter. Its value derives from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the phi31 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviation are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Core/PhotVariableTimeSeriesGccd
table.description: per-CCD time series of sources that have the photometric variability flag in CatalogueSource set to true.

parameter.name: numObservations
parameter.description: Number of CCD observations in this time series
parameter.detailed-description: This number simply indicates the length of the time series arrays. For this per-CCD time series always 10 entries per transit are exported, i.e., for SM, AF1, ..., AF9. So the number of transits is simply given by numObservations/10. Entries that are unavailable or invalid are indicated using the Double.NaN value.

parameter.name: observationTimes
parameter.description: Barycentric light-travel time corrected timestamp for each CCD observation
parameter.detailed-description:
Barycentric light-travel time corrected timestamps for the per-CCD observation times. This correction is applied to shift observation times at Gaia to a virtual observer at the solar system barycentre, removing the time distortion caused by the Roemer effect.
The times are in TCB (i.e. the clock ticking at the baricentre).
A reference time offset of $T_0$ = 2455197.5 days (= J2010.0 = 2010-01-01T00:00:00) is applied according to the Gaia convention, i.e.,\\ observationTimes[i] = baricentricObsTimeJulianDateInTcb - $T_0$.
For this per-CCD time series there are always 10 entries per transit exported, i.e., for SM, AF1, ..., AF9. If an entry is not available it is set to Double.NaN. For array index position i (starting at 0), you can recover the:\\ - ccdIndex = i \% 10 \\ - transitIndex = (int) i / 10 \\ The ccd index correspond to the following CCD:\\ \begin{tabular}{rl} \bf ccdIndex & \bf CCD\\ 0 & SM \\ 1 & AF1 \\ 2 & AF2 \\ 3 & AF3 \\ 4 & AF4 \\ 5 & AF5 \\ 6 & AF6 \\ 7 & AF7 \\ 8 & AF8 \\ 9 & AF9 \\ \end{tabular}

parameter.name: transitIds
parameter.description: The transit identifier for each CCD observation [REMOVE? NOT PER CCD]
parameter.detailed-description: These are direct correspondences to the Gaia transitids for each individual fov transit. The definition of the transitId is described in: GAIA-C3-TN-UB-JP-011.

parameter.name: flags

parameter.detailed-description: These are the CCD G-band fluxes. Always 10 entries per transit are exported, i.e., for SM, AF1, ..., AF9. If an entry is not available it is set to Double.NaN. For array index position i (starting at 0), you can recover the:\\ - ccdIndex = i \% 10 \\ - transitIndex = (int) i / 10 \\ The ccd index correspond to the following CCD:\\ \begin{tabular}{rl} \bf ccdIndex & \bf CCD\\ 0 & SM \\ 1 & AF1 \\ 2 & AF2 \\ 3 & AF3 \\ 4 & AF4 \\ 5 & AF5 \\ 6 & AF6 \\ 7 & AF7 \\ 8 & AF8 \\ 9 & AF9 \\ \end{tabular}

If an entry is not available it is set to Double.NaN. For array index position i (starting at 0), you can recover the:\\ - ccdIndex = i \% 10 \\ - transitIndex = (int) i / 10 \\ The ccd index correspond to the following CCD:\\ \begin{tabular}{rl} \bf ccdIndex & \bf CCD\\ 0 & SM \\ 1 & AF1 \\ 2 & AF2 \\ 3 & AF3 \\ 4 & AF4 \\ 5 & AF5 \\ 6 & AF6 \\ 7 & AF7 \\ 8 & AF8 \\ 9 & AF9 \\ \end{tabular}

For array index position i (starting at 0), you can recover the:\\ - ccdIndex = i \% 10 \\ - transitIndex = (int) i / 10 \\ The ccd index correspond to the following CCD:\\ \begin{tabular}{rl} \bf ccdIndex & \bf CCD\\ 0 & SM \\ 1 & AF1 \\ 2 & AF2 \\ 3 & AF3 \\ 4 & AF4 \\ 5 & AF5 \\ 6 & AF6 \\ 7 & AF7 \\ 8 & AF8 \\ 9 & AF9 \\ \end{tabular}

parameter.name: weightedSkewness
parameter.description: Standardized weighted skewness of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased weighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{E}_w$ denote the sample-size biased weighted skewness moment: \[ \mathcal{E}_w= \frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^3 \] where $W=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized biased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}_{w}$ is the square root of the biased weighted variance around the weighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased weighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0 with size $N > 2$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{E}_w$ denote the sample-size unbiased weighted skewness moment: \[ \mathcal{E}_w= \frac{V_1^2}{V_1^3-3V_1V_2+2V_3}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^3 \] where $V_p=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i^p$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized unbiased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}_{w}$ is the square root of the unbiased weighted variance around the weighted mean. While $\mathcal{E}_{w}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $E$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.name: weightedKurtosis
parameter.description: Standardized weighted kurtosis of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased weighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{K}_w$ denote the sample-size biased weighted kurtosis cumulant: \[ \mathcal{K}_w =\frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^4 - 3 \left[\frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^2\right]^2 \] where $W=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized biased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2_{w}$ is the biased weighted variance around the weighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased weighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0 with size $N > 3$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{K}_w$ denote the sample-size unbiased weighted kurtosis cumulant: \[ \mathcal{K}_w =\frac{V_1(V_1^4-4V_1V_3+3V_2^2)}{(V_1^2-V_2)(V_1^4-6V_1^2V_2+8V_1V_3+3V_2^2-6V_4)}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^4 + ~~~~~~~~ \] \[ ~~~~~~~~ -\frac{3(V_1^4-2V_1^2V_2+4V_1V_3-3V_2^2)}{(V_1^2-V_2)(V_1^4-6V_1^2V_2+8V_1V_3+3V_2^2-6V_4)}\,\left[\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^2\right]^2 \] where $V_p=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i^p$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized unbiased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2_{w}$ is the unbiased weighted variance around the weighted mean. While $\mathcal{K}_{w}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $K$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.name: weightedNormalizedP2pScatter
parameter.description: Weighted normalized point-to-point scatter of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: stdDev
parameter.description: Square root of the unweighted variance of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The square root of the biased unweighted variance. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The unweighted standard deviation $\hat{\sigma}$ is defined as the square root of the sample-size biased unweighted variance: \[ \hat{\sigma}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2 }. \] \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The square root of the unbiased unweighted variance. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia residual time series containing all observations with CU7-reject flag = 0 with size $N > 1$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The unweighted standard deviation $\hat{\sigma}$ is defined as the square root of the sample-size unbiased unweighted variance: \[ \hat{\sigma}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N-1}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2 }. \] \end{description}

parameter.name: skewness
parameter.description: Standardized unweighted skewness of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased unweighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size biased unweighted skewness moment $\mathcal{E}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{E}= \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(y_i-\overline{y})^3. \] The standardized biased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}$ is the square root of the biased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased unweighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia residual time series containing all observations with CU7-reject flag = 0 with size $N > 2$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size unbiased unweighted skewness moment $\mathcal{E}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{E}= \frac{N}{(N-1)(N-2)}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(y_i-\overline{y})^3. \] The standardized unbiased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}$ is the square root of the unbiased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. While $\mathcal{E}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $E$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.name: kurtosis
parameter.description: Standardized unweighted kurtosis of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased unweighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size biased unweighted kurtosis cumulant $\mathcal{K}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{K} =\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^4 -3 \left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2\right]^2. \] The standardized biased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2$ is the biased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased unweighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0 with size $N > 3$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size unbiased unweighted kurtosis cumulant $\mathcal{K}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{K} =\frac{N(N+1)}{(N-1)(N-2)(N-3)}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^4 -\frac{3}{(N-2)(N-3)}\,\left[\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2\right]^2. \] The standardized unbiased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2$ is the unbiased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. While $\mathcal{K}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $K$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.description: Time duration of the time series (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description: Duration of Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0.

parameter.description: Median Absolute Deviation (MAD) of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Core/PhotVariableTimeSeriesGfov
table.description: per-FOV time series of sources that have the photometric variability flag in CatalogueSource set to true.

parameter.name: numObservations
parameter.description: Number of FOV observations in this time series
parameter.detailed-description: The length of the time series arrays. For this per-field-of-view time series only one field-of-view average entry per transit is exported. Entries that are unavailable or invalid are indicated using the Double.NaN value.

parameter.name: observationTimes
parameter.description: Barycentric light-travel time corrected timestamp for each FOV observation
parameter.detailed-description:
Barycentric light-travel time corrected timestamps for the per-fov transit averaged observation times. This correction is applied to shift observation times at Gaia to a virtual observer at the solar system barycentre, removing the time distortion caused by the Roemer effect.
The times are in TCB (i.e. the clock ticking at the baricentre).
A reference time offset of $T_0$ = 2455197.5 days (=J2010.0 = 2010-01-01T00:00:00) is applied according to the Gaia convention, i.e.,\\ observationTimes[i] = baricentricObsTimeJulianDateInTcb - $T_0$.
If a value is not available it is set to Double.NaN.

parameter.name: transitIds
parameter.description: The transit identifier for each FOV observation
parameter.detailed-description: These are direct correspondences to the Gaia transitids for each individual fov transit. The definition of the transitId is described in: GAIA-C3-TN-UB-JP-011.

parameter.name: flags
parameter.detailed-description:
Description of the meaning of the flags is: \\ \textbf{TODO: UPDATE FULL FLAG LIST JAN 2016 WHEN IT IS KNOWN WHICH FLAGS TO EXPORT} Possibly extending CU5 flags:
\begin{tabular}{lrll} \bf Bit & \bf Value & \bf Name & \bf Description\\ 0 & 1 & Noisy data & Set if variation in G-band fluxes is larger than expected.\\ 1 & 2 & Overall reject & Indicates that the whole FoV transit has been rejected.\\ 2 & 4 & SM reject & The SM transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 3 & 8 & AF1 reject & The AF1 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 4 & 16 & AF2 reject & The AF2 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 5 & 32 & AF3 reject & The AF3 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 6 & 64 & AF4 reject & The AF4 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 7 & 128 & AF5 reject & The AF5 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 8 & 256 & AF6 reject & The AF6 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 9 & 512 & AF7 reject & The AF7 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 10 & 1024 & AF8 reject & The AF8 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 11 & 2048 & AF9 reject & The AF9 transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 12 & 4096 & BP reject & The BP transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 13 & 8192 & RP reject & The RP transit has been rejected or was unavailable.\\ 14 & 16384 & BP contaminated & The BP transit is contaminated.\\ 15 & 32768 & BP blended & The BP transit is a blended image.\\ 16 & 65536 & RP contaminated & The RP transit is contaminated.\\ 17 & 131072 & RP blended & The RP transit is a blended image.\\
31 & 2147483648 & CU7 reject & The observation was rejected by CU7 for variability analyses. \\ \end{tabular}
Bits 18 to 30 are currently undefined and are for future use.

parameter.name: gFluxes
parameter.description: G band flux for each FOV averaged observation
parameter.detailed-description: G-band fluxes for the per-fov transit averaged observations. If a value is not available it is set to Double.NaN.

parameter.name: gFluxErrors
parameter.description: Estimated flux uncertainty for each FOV averaged observation
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated G-band fluxes uncertainties for the per-fov transit averaged observations. If a value is not available it is set to Double.NaN.

parameter.name: gMagnitudes
parameter.description: G band magnitude for each FOV averaged observation
parameter.detailed-description: G-band fluxes for the per-fov transit averaged observations, for magnitude zero-point see table ExtPhotZeroPoint. If a value is not available it is set to Double.NaN.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: numObservationsProcessed
parameter.description: Number of observations processed, i.e, with CU7 reject flag=0

parameter.name: meanObsTime
min
parameter.description: Minimum value of the time series (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description: Minimum value of Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0.

parameter.name: max
parameter.description: Maximum value of the time series (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description: Max value of Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0.

parameter.name: mean
parameter.description: Mean of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: meanError
parameter.description: Mean of the uncertainties of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: weightedMean
parameter.description: Weighted mean of time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: median
parameter.description: Median of time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: medianError
parameter.description: Median of the uncertainties of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: range
parameter.description: Difference between the highest and lowest values of the time series (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: trimmedWeightedMean
parameter.description: Trimmed Weighted Mean of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: trimmedWeightedRange
parameter.description: Trimmed Weighted Range of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: weightedStdDev
parameter.description: Weighted standard deviation of the time series values around the weighted mean (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: WeightedMeanConfidenceIntervalWidth
parameter.description: Width of the confidence interval for the weighted mean of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: weightedSkewness
parameter.description: Standardized weighted skewness of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased weighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{E}_w$ denote the sample-size biased weighted skewness moment: \[ \mathcal{E}_w= \frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^3 \] where $W=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized biased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}_{w}$ is the square root of the biased weighted variance around the weighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased weighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0 with size $N > 2$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{E}_w$ denote the sample-size unbiased weighted skewness moment: \[ \mathcal{E}_w= \frac{V_1^2}{V_1^3-3V_1V_2+2V_3}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^3 \] where $V_p=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i^p$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized unbiased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}_{w}$ is the square root of the unbiased weighted variance around the weighted mean. While $\mathcal{E}_{w}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $E$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.name: weightedKurtosis
parameter.description: Standardized weighted kurtosis of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased weighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{K}_w$ denote the sample-size biased weighted kurtosis cumulant: \[ \mathcal{K}_w =\frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^4 - 3 \left[\frac{1}{W}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^2\right]^2 \] where $W=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized biased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2_{w}$ is the biased weighted variance around the weighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased weighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0 with size $N > 3$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$, with error bars $\Delta y_{i}$ and weights $w_{i}$ [which might equal $(\Delta y_{i})^{-2}$]. Let $\mathcal{K}_w$ denote the sample-size unbiased weighted kurtosis cumulant: \[ \mathcal{K}_w =\frac{V_1(V_1^4-4V_1V_3+3V_2^2)}{(V_1^2-V_2)(V_1^4-6V_1^2V_2+8V_1V_3+3V_2^2-6V_4)}\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^4 + ~~~~~~~~ \] \[ ~~~~~~~~ -\frac{3(V_1^4-2V_1^2V_2+4V_1V_3-3V_2^2)}{(V_1^2-V_2)(V_1^4-6V_1^2V_2+8V_1V_3+3V_2^2-6V_4)}\,\left[\sum_{i=1}^{N}w_i (y_i-\overline{y}_w)^2\right]^2 \] where $V_p=\sum_{i=1}^N w_i^p$ and $\overline{y}_{w}$ is the weighted mean.\\ The standardized unbiased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}_{w}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}_{w}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2_{w}$ is the unbiased weighted variance around the weighted mean. While $\mathcal{K}_{w}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $K$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.name: weightedNormalizedP2pScatter
parameter.description: Weighted normalized point-to-point scatter of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)

parameter.name: stdDev
parameter.description: Square root of the unweighted variance of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The square root of the biased unweighted variance. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The unweighted standard deviation $\hat{\sigma}$ is defined as the square root of the sample-size biased unweighted variance: \[ \hat{\sigma}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2 }. \] \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The square root of the unbiased unweighted variance. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia residual time series containing all observations with CU7-reject flag = 0 with size $N > 1$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The unweighted standard deviation $\hat{\sigma}$ is defined as the square root of the sample-size unbiased unweighted variance: \[ \hat{\sigma}=\sqrt{\frac{1}{N-1}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2 }. \] \end{description}

parameter.name: skewness
parameter.description: Standardized unweighted skewness of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased unweighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size biased unweighted skewness moment $\mathcal{E}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{E}= \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(y_i-\overline{y})^3. \] The standardized biased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}$ is the square root of the biased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased unweighted skewness. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia residual time series containing all observations with CU7-reject flag = 0 with size $N > 2$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size unbiased unweighted skewness moment $\mathcal{E}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{E}= \frac{N}{(N-1)(N-2)}\sum_{i=1}^{N}(y_i-\overline{y})^3. \] The standardized unbiased skewness $E$ is defined as: \[ E= \frac{\mathcal{E}}{\hat{\sigma}^{3}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}$ is the square root of the unbiased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. While $\mathcal{E}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $E$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}

parameter.name: kurtosis
parameter.description: Standardized unweighted kurtosis of the time series values (CU7 reject flag=0)
parameter.detailed-description:
\textbf{SELECT DESCRIPTION TO STAY IN JAN 2016 WHEN WE KNOW IF WE USE BIAS CORRECTED OR NOT (THE REFERENCE TO THE FLAG WILL BE REMOVED TOO)} If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is FALSE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised biased unweighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size biased unweighted kurtosis cumulant $\mathcal{K}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{K} =\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^4 -3 \left[\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2\right]^2. \] The standardized biased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2$ is the biased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. \\ \end{description}
If the bias correction flag (in the field `SolutionIdScienceMetadata.isStatisticalParamBiasCorrected') is TRUE, the following definition applies: \begin{description} \item[] \textbf{Name:} The standardised unbiased unweighted kurtosis. \item[] \textbf{Input:} Gaia time series containing only observations with CU7 reject flag=0 with size $N > 3$. \item[] \textbf{Output:} Let $y_{i}$ be a time series of size $N$. The sample-size unbiased unweighted kurtosis cumulant $\mathcal{K}$ is defined as: \[ \mathcal{K} =\frac{N(N+1)}{(N-1)(N-2)(N-3)}\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^4 -\frac{3}{(N-2)(N-3)}\,\left[\sum_{i=1}^{N} (y_i-\overline{y})^2\right]^2. \] The standardized unbiased kurtosis $K$ is defined as: \[ K= \frac{\mathcal{K}}{\hat{\sigma}^{4}} \] where $\hat{\sigma}^2$ is the unbiased unweighted variance around the unweighted mean. While $\mathcal{K}$ is an unbiased estimate of the population value, $K$ becomes unbiased in the limit of large $N$. \end{description}
