table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Core/RRLyrae
table.description: This table describes the identified RRLyrae stars. The processed Gaia time series contain all observations with CU7-reject flag=0, as found in PhotVariableTimeSeriesGfov table.

parameter.name: rrlClassification
parameter.description: RR Lyrae type classification for the target star: RRLclassification[]=[ProbToBeRRc, ProbToBeRRab] (Null if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the RR Lyrae classification type. The parameter type is an array of doubles, its values represents the percentages of belonging to: {\it RRc}, {\it RRab} types.

parameter.name: rrlBestClassification
parameter.description: Best RR Lyrae classification estimate out of: {"RRC", "RRAB"} (Null if absent)

parameter.name: rrlDoubleFlag
parameter.description: flag filled with ”true” or “false” whether or not the target is a double-mode RR Lyrae star. (Null if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this flag is filled with "true" or ``false'' whether or not the target is a double-mode RR Lyrae star.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: PF
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the fundamental pulsation mode (for multi mode pulsators) in the G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: PF: for pulsators with one secondary periodicity this parameter is filled with the period corresponding to the longer periodicity. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The parameter type is double and its value ranges from 0.1 to hundreds of days depending on the variable star type.

parameter.name: PFError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the PF period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
PFerror: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it PF} parameter.
The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P1O
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the first overtone pulsation mode (for multi mode pulsators) in the G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P1O: for pulsators with one secondary periodicity this parameter is filled with the period corresponding to the shorter periodicity. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P1OError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the P1O period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P1OError: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it P1O} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P2O
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the second overtone pulsation mode (for multi mode pulsators) in the G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P2O: for multimode pulsators with three periodicities this parameter is filled with the period corresponding to third and shorter periodicity, already called {\it p2} (see above), whereas P1O and PF are the intermediate, and the longer periodicities, respectively. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time-series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: P2OError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the P2O period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: P2OError: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it P2O} parameter, already called {\it p3Error} (see above). The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time-series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p1
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the maximum power peak in the periodogram of G band time series (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the period of the maximum power peak in the frequencygram obtained from the modeling of the time series. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the G-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double and its value ranges from 0.1 to hundreds of days depending on the variable star type.

parameter.name: p1Error
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the p1 period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it p1} parameter. Its value is derived with Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the period is derived from the non linear modeling with a truncated Fourier series of the light curve. The mean of all the periods found and its standard deviation are then computed, and the latter value is kept as value to fill the {\it periodError} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p2
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the second maximum power peak in the periodogram of G band time series (for multi-mode pulsators) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the second periodicity for variable stars. The value is obtained modeling the time series using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p2Error
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the p2 period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it p2} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the p2 is computed. The mean of all the periods and its standard deviation are then computed, and the latter value is kept as value to fill the {\it p2Error} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p3
parameter.description: Period corresponding to the third maximum power peak in the periodogram of G band time series (for multi-mode pulsators) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the third periodicity value for variable stars. The value is obtained modeling the time series using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The value refers to the analysis performed on the $G$ band time series. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: p3Error
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the p3 period (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it p3} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the p3 is computed. The mean of all the periods found and its standard deviation are then computed, and the latter value is kept to fill the {\it p3Error} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: epochG
parameter.description: Epoch of the maximum of the light curve in the G band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
this parameter is filled with the epoch of maximum light epoch for the Gaia G band. It corresponds to the Baricentric Julian day (BJD) of the maximum value of the light curve model which is closer to the BJD of the first observations -3$\times$(Period of the variable). The type of this parameter is double.
The mentioned BJD is offset by the Gaia default of JD 2455197.5 (= J2010.0).

parameter.name: epochBp
parameter.description: Epoch of the maximum of the light curve in the BP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
this parameter is filled with the epoch of maximum light epoch for the Gaia integrated BP band. It corresponds to the Baricentric Julian day (BJD) of the maximum value of the light curve model which is closer to the BJD of the first observations -3$\times$(Period of the variable). The type of this parameter is double.
The mentioned BJD is offset by the Gaia default of JD 2455197.5 (= J2010.0).

parameter.name: epochRp
parameter.description: Epoch of the maximum of the light curve in the RP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description:
this parameter is filled with the epoch of maximum light epoch for the Gaia integrated RP band. It corresponds to the Baricentric Julian day (BJD) of the maximum value of the light curve model which is closer to the BJD of the first observations -3$\times$(Period of the variable). The type of this parameter is double.
The mentioned BJD is offset by the Gaia default of JD 2455197.5 (= J2010.0).

parameter.name: epochGError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the epoch parameter epochG (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it epochG} parameter. Its value is three times the error on the period. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: epochBpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the epoch parameter epochBp (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it epochBp} parameter. Its value is three times the error on the period. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: epochRpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the epoch parameter epochRp (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it epochRp} parameter. Its value is three times the error on the period. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageG
parameter.description: intensity-averaged magnitude in the G band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the intensity-averaged magnitude in the $G$-band. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageGError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on intAverageG parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with uncertainty value of the {\it intAverageG} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageBp
parameter.description: intensity-averaged magnitude in the BP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the intensity-averaged magnitude in the $G_{BP}$-band. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageBpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on intAverageBp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with uncertainty value of the {\it intAverageBp} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageRp
parameter.description: intensity-averaged magnitude in the RP band (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the intensity-averaged magnitude in the $G_{RP}$-band. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: intAverageRpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on intAverageRp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with uncertainty value of the {\it intAverageRp} parameter. The type of this parameter is double.

parameter.name: averageRvError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on averageRv parameter (0 if absent)

parameter.name: peakToPeakG
parameter.description: Peak-to-peak amplitude of the G band light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the peak-to-peak amplitude value of the $G$ band light curve. The peak-to-peak amplitude is calculated as the (maximum) - (minimum) of the folded modeled light curve in the $G$ band. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $G$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakGError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the peakToPeakG parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it peakToPeakG} parameter. The uncertainty is computed as the $\sqrt{2} error(Zp)$, where $Zp$ is the zero point obtained by the non linear fourier modeling of the light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakBp
parameter.description: Peak-to-peak amplitude of the BP band light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the peak-to-peak amplitude value value of the $BP$ light curve. The peak-to-peak amplitude is calculated as the (maximum) - (minimum) of the folded modeled light curve in the $BP$ band. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $BP$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakBpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the peakToPeakBp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it peakToPeakBp} parameter. The uncertainty is computed as the $\sqrt{2} error(Zp)$, where $Zp$ is the zero point obtained by the non linear fourier modeling of the light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakRp
parameter.description: Peak-to-peak amplitude of the RP band light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the peak-to-peak amplitude value. The peak-to-peak amplitude is calculated as the (maximum) - (minimum) of the folded modeled light curve in the $RP$ band. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $RP$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: peakToPeakRpError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the peakToPeakRp parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value of the {\it peakToPeakRp} parameter. The uncertainty is computed as the $\sqrt{2} error(Zp)$, where $Zp$ is the zero point obtained by the non linear fourier modeling of the light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: metallicity
parameter.description: Metallicity of the star from the Fourier parameters of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: metallicity: this parameter is filled with the [Fe/H] metallicity derived for the source from the Fourier parameters of the G-band light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: metallicityError
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the metallicity parameter (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: metallicityError: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it metallicity} derived from the Fourier parameters of the G-band light curve. The parameter type is double.

parameter.name: numHarmonicsForP1
parameter.description: Number of harmonics used to model P1 of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the number of harmonics used to model P1 of the light curve. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. If the target star is a multi-mode pulsator, the previous sum is extended to all existing periodicities. The parameter type is an integer and refers to the $G$-band light curve analysis.

parameter.name: numHarmonicsForP2
parameter.description: Number of harmonics used to model P2 of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the number of harmonics used to model P2 of the light curve. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. If the target star is a multi-mode pulsator, the previous sum is extended to all existing periodicities. The parameter type is an integer and refers to the $G$-band light curve analysis.

parameter.name: numHarmonicsForP3
parameter.description: Number of harmonics used to model P3 of the light curve (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the number of harmonics used to model P3 of the light curve. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. If the target star is a multi-mode pulsator, the previous sum is extended to all existing periodicities. The parameter type is an integer and refers to the $G$-band light curve analysis.

parameter.name: r11G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter r21G: A2/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $R_{21} = A_2/A_1$. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $R_{i1}$ is defined as, $A_{i}/A_{1}$ where $A_{i}$ is the amplitude of the {\it i}th harmonic and $A_{1}$ is the amplitude of the foundamental harmonic of the truncated Fourier series defined above. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: r31G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter r31G: A3/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $R_{31} = A_3/A_1$. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max}t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $R_{i1}$ is defined as, $A_{i}/A_{1}$ where $A_{i}$ is the amplitude of the {\it i}th harmonic and $A_{1}$ is the amplitude of the foundamental harmonic of the truncated Fourier series defined above. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: r21GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the r21G parameter: A2/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value on the {\it r11G} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the ri1 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviations are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value is derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: r31GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the r31G parameter: A3/A1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty value on the {\it r31G} parameter. Its value is derived from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the ri1 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviations are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value is derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi21G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter phi21G: phi2 − 2*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $\phi_{21}$: $\phi_2 - 2\phi_1$ value. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max} t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $G$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $\phi_{i1}$ is defined as, $\phi_{i}- i \times \phi_{1}$. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi31G
parameter.description: Fourier decomposition parameter phi31G: phi3 − 3*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the Fourier decomposition parameter $\phi_{31}$: $\phi_3 - 3\phi_1$ value. The light curve of the target star is modeled with a truncated Fourier series ($mag(t_j)=zp+\sum[A_i sin(i \times 2 \pi \nu_{max} t_j +\phi_i)]$). Zero-point (zp), period (1/$\nu_{max}$), number of harmonics ($i$), amplitudes ($A_i$), and phases ($\phi_i$) of the harmonics, for the $G$-band light curve are determined using the Levenberg-Marquardt non linear fitting algorithm. The $\phi_{i1}$ is defined as, $\phi_{i}- i \times \phi_{1}$. The parameter type is double, its value is from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi21GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the phi21G parameter: phi2 − 2*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it phi21G}: $\phi_2 - 2\phi_1$ parameter. Its value derives from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the phi21 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviation are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: phi31GError
parameter.description: Uncertainty on the phi31G parameter: phi3 − 3*phi1 (for G band) (0 if absent)
parameter.detailed-description: this parameter is filled with the uncertainty of the {\it phi31G}: $\phi_3 - 3\phi_1$ parameter. Its value derives from Monte Carlo simulations that generate several (100) time series with the same time path as the data points but with magnitudes generated randomly around the corresponding data value. For each of these time series the phi31 values are computed. The mean for each of these values and their standard deviation are then computed, and the latter values are kept as value to fill the parameter. The type of this parameter is double, the value derive from the analysis of the $G$-band time series.

parameter.name: numberOfGbandEpochs
parameter.description: Number of epochs used in the fitting algorithm

parameter.name: amplitudesFirstPeriod
parameter.description: Amplitudes of the p1 harmonics (empty if absent)

parameter.name: phasesFirstPeriod
parameter.description: Phases of the p1 harmonics (empty if absent)

parameter.name: amplitudesSecondPeriod
parameter.description: Amplitudes of the p2 harmonics (empty if absent)

parameter.name: phasesSecondPeriod
parameter.description: Phases of the p2 harmonics (empty if absent)

parameter.name: zeroPoint
parameter.description: Zero point of the modeled Fourier series (0 if absent)

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Core/ShortTimescale
table.description: This table describes the identified short-timescale sources. The processed Gaia time series contain all observations with CU7-reject flag=0, as found in PhotVariableTimeSeriesGfov table.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: amplitudeEstimate
parameter.description: Amplitude estimate of all per CCD G-band photometry (quantile(95%)-quantile(5%))

parameter.name: meanOfSquaredFovSlopes
parameter.description: Mean of squared per-FOV slopes derived from CCD G-band photometry

parameter.name: meanOfSquaredFovSlopesErrors
parameter.description: Uncertainty of the mean of squared per-FOV slopes derived from CCD G-band photometry

parameter.name: numberOfFovTransits
parameter.description: Number of FOV transits (= number of averaged slopes)

parameter.name: slopeVariabilityFlag
parameter.description: Variability detection flag based on G-band per-FOV slopes derived from CCD G-band photometry

parameter.name: variogramVariabilityFlag
parameter.description: Variability detection flag based on the variogram

parameter.name: frequency
parameter.description: Found frequency for G-band photometry using Bartlett method (0 if no periodicity detected)

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Core/TgasSource
table.description: A subset of around 2.5 million entries in CatalogueSource which are present in the Tycho2 catalogue and hence have early epoch positions enabling full 5-parameter solutions, including parallaxes, in combination with Gaia Data Release 1.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: randomIndex
parameter.description: Random index used to select subsets
parameter.detailed-description:
Random index which can be used in order to select smaller subsets of the data that are still representative. This can be useful for validation (testing on 10 different random subsets), visualization (displaying 1% of the data) and exploring the data, without having to load/download all data.
The column should have non-repeating/unique long, preferably without any missing numbers between 0 and N-1 (where N is the numbers of rows).
This column should be just a counter which gets populated in a totatly random way.

parameter.name: refEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: The reference epoch to which the astrometic source parameters are referred to expressed as a Julian Year in TCB.

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: Longitude (Right Ascension) $\alpha$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: raError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\alpha *$ of longitude (Right Ascension) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch} times $\cos(\delta)$.

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: Latitude (Declination) $\delta$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: decError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\delta$ of latitude (Declination) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: parallax
parameter.detailed-description: Absolute stellar parallax $\varpi$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: parallaxError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\varpi$ of absolute stellar parallax at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: pmra
parameter.description: Proper motion in right ascension direction
parameter.detailed-description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\alpha*}$

parameter.name: pmraError
parameter.description: Standard error of proper motion in right ascension direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\alpha*}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing right ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: pmdec
parameter.detailed-description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\delta}$

parameter.name: pmdecError
parameter.description: Standard error of proper motion in declination direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\delta}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: pmradial
parameter.detailed-description: The Radial proper motion $\mu_r$ of the source calculated from the {\em spectroscopically} determined radial velocity $v_r$, the parallax $\varpi$, and the value of the astronomical unit as $\mu_r=v_r\varpi/A$ in units of [mas/yr].

parameter.name: pmradialError
parameter.description: Standard error of proper motion in radial direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error of $\mu_r$ (in the same units) calculated by the soure update if $\mu_r$ has been solved for. Otherwise the error is calculated in the standard way from the standard errors of $v_r$ and $\varpi$. If the radial velocity is unknown a standard error of 100 km/s will be assumed for the error calculation.

parameter.name: raDecCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and declination
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: raParallaxCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and parallax
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: raPmraCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion right ascension
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: raPmdecCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion declination
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: raPmradialCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion radial
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion radial in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: decParallaxCorr
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between declination and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: decPmraCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion right ascension
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between declination and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: decPmdecCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion declination
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between declination and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: decPmradialCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between declination and proper motion radial
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between declination and proper motion radial in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: parallaxPmraCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion right ascension
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: parallaxPmdecCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion declination
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: parallaxPmradialCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion radial
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between parallax and proper motion radial in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: pmraPmdecCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between proper motion right ascension and proper motion declination
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between proper motion right ascension and proper motion declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: pmraPmradialCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between proper motion right ascension and proper motion radial
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between proper motion right ascension and proper motion radial in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: pmdecPmradialCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between proper motion declination and proper motion radial
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between proper motion declination and proper motion radial in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: astrometricNObsAl
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) AL that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

parameter.name: astrometricNObsAc
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) in AC that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

parameter.name: astrometricNOutliersAl
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AL. Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

parameter.name: astrometricNOutliersAc
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AC (second element). Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

parameter.name: astrometricGoF
parameter.detailed-description:
$	t f2$ is the `gaussianized chi-square' indicating the goodness-of-fit of the astrometric solution to the accepted data. For good fits, $	t f2$ should approximately follow a normal distribution with zero mean value and unit standard deviation. $	t f2$ values exceeding, say, +3 thus indicate a bad fit to the data. An alternative indicator of bad fits is the $	t excessNoise$ (see below).
The statistic $	t f2$ was computed from the goodness-of-fit statistic $\chi^2$ (see below) and $
u$, the number of degrees of freedom, according to the formula:
${m f2}=(9
u/2)^{1/2} [(\chi^2/
u)^{1/3} + 2 / (9
u) -1]$
This formula is the well-known cube-root transformation of the chi-square variable (E.B. Wilson \& M.M. Hilferty 1931, Proc. National Academy of Science, 17, 684). It is usually quoted to be valid for $
u > 30$, but is in fact useful for much smaller $
u$. The transformation of $(\chi^2,
u)$ to f2 eliminates the inconvenience of having the distribution (and hence the significance levels) depend on the additional variable $
u$, which is generally not the same for different sources.
For a source update with $N$ astrometric parameters (see ${	t paramsSolved}$), $\chi^2$ and $
u$ were computed as
$\chi^2 = {	t chi2}[0] + {	t chi2}[1]$,
$
u = {	t nObs}[0] + {	t nObs}[1] - N$.
The `unit weight error' of the solution is given by $(\chi^2/
u)^{1/2}$, which is expected to be $\simeq 1.0$ for a good solution, but unlike f2 its distribution still depends on $
u$.
In AGIS the source update deals with bad fits (large $	t f2$) by adding $	t excessNoise$ to the formal observation noise. This effectively reduces the unit weight error of the fit to 1.0 and inflates the covariance of the estimated astrometric parameters correspondingly. However, the chi-square values ${	t chi2}[]$ used to calculate $	t f2$ do not take into account the $	t excessNoise$, and $	t f2$ can therefore always be used as a goodness-of-fit indicator of the source solution in AGIS. The excessNoise provides an alternative indicator of bad fits, although it may be 0 for good fits (unit weight error $\le 1$, roughly corresponding to negative $	t f2$). The actual amount of excess noise used in the fit (and covariance calculation) is given by $	t excessNoise$ if ${	t excessNoiseSig}>2$, otherwise it is 0 (even though $	t excessNoise$ may be positive).

parameter.name: astrometricChi2Al
parameter.detailed-description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AL direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

parameter.name: astrometricChi2Ac
parameter.detailed-description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AC direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

parameter.name: astrometricDeltaQ
parameter.detailed-description:
In the HTPM solution $\tt deltaQ$ indicates the discrepancy between the Hipparcos data and the Gaia data when a single model of uniform space motion is fitted to both datasets. A large value of $\tt deltaQ$ could indicate non-linear motion (e.g.\ in a binary).
$\tt deltaQ$ shows how much the $\chi^2$ of the joint solution increases by fitting a single set of five astrometric parameters to the data, rather than two independent sets of five parameter each. See D. Michalik et al. 2014, \emph{Joint astrometric solution of Hipparcos and Gaia: A recipe for the Hundred Thousand Proper Motions project} (submitted to A\&A) for details.

parameter.name: astrometricExcessNoise
parameter.detailed-description:
This is the excess noise $\epsilon_i$ of the source. It measures how much the assumed observational noise in each observation must be (quadratically) increased in order to give $\chi^2=\nu$ in the astrometric solution of the source. A value of 0 signifies that the source is astrometrically well-behaved, i.e.\ that the residuals of the fit statistically agree with the assumed observational noise ($\chi^2\le\nu$).
The significance of $\tt excessNoise$ is given by $\tt excessNoiseSig$. If ${\tt excessNoiseSig}\le 2$ then $\tt excessNoise$ is probably not significant, and the source may be astrometrically well-behaved even if $\tt excessNoise$ is large.
Independent of the given value of $\tt excessNoise$, the `gaussianized chi-square' $\tt f2$ is always calculated using ${\tt excessNoise}=0$.
The excess source noise is further explained in Sects.~3.6 and 5.1.2 of \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

parameter.name: astrometricExcessNoiseSig
parameter.detailed-description: A dimensionless measure ($D$) of the significance of the calculated $\tt excessNoise$ ($\epsilon_i$). A value $D>2$ indicates that the given $\tt excessNoise$ is probably significant.

parameter.name: astrometricParamsSolved
parameter.description: Which parameters have been solved for?
parameter.detailed-description:
The 6 least-significant bits of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ indicate which astrometric parameters have been estimated for this source. A set bit means the parameter was updated, an unset bit means the parameter was not updated. The least-significant bit corresponds to $\alpha$. The table below shows the values of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ for relevant combinations of the parameters.
Each AGIS run starts with a target number $N$ (usually = 5) of astrometric parameters to solve for, with the following mapping:
\begin{tabular}{lccccccc} $N$ & ${\tt paramsSolved}$ & $\alpha$ & $\delta$ & $\varpi$ & $\mu_{\alpha*}$ & $\mu_\delta $ & $\mu_r$ \\\hline 2 & 3 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & & \\ 3 & 7 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & \\ 4 & 27 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 5 & 31 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 6 & 63 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$\\\hline \end{tabular}
For each source, however, an $N$-parameter update could fail (e.g.\ because there is an insufficient number of observations or their temporal distribution does not allow the update) and in this case a fallback option with a smaller value of $N$ is attempted.

parameter.name: astrometricRankDefect
parameter.detailed-description: The rank defect of the astrometric solution of the source. This should normally be zero, signaling that the rank of the least-squares system for the solution equals the number of estimated parameters (the binary digit sum of ${\tt paramsSolved}$). A positive value means that the astrometric solution of the source is most likely wrong.

parameter.name: astrometricPrimaryFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Flag indicating if this source was used as a primary source ($\tt true$) or secondary source ($\tt false$). Only primary sources contribute to the estimation of attitude, calibration, and global parameters. The estimation of source parameters is otherwise done in exactly the same way for primary and secondary sources.

parameter.name: astrometricRelegationFactor
parameter.detailed-description: Relegation factor of the source calculated as per Eq.~(118) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain} used for the primary selection process.

parameter.name: astrometricWeightAl
parameter.description: Mean astrometric weight of the source
parameter.detailed-description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the ALdirection.
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

parameter.name: astrometricWeightAc
parameter.description: Mean astrometric weight of the source
parameter.detailed-description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the AC direction
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

parameter.name: astrometricPriorsUsed
parameter.description: Type of prior used in in the astrometric solution
parameter.detailed-description: Type of prior used in the astrometric solution: \begin{itemize} \item 0: No prior used \item 1: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion \item 2: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion relaxed by factor 10 \item 3: Hipparcos prior for position \item 4: Hipparcos prior for position and proper motion \item 5: Tycho2 prior for position \item 6: Quasar prior for proper motion \end{itemize}

parameter.name: matchedObservations
parameter.description: Amount of observations matched to this source
parameter.detailed-description:
A given source will never be removed from the MDB catalog. Instead, it may simply be left without any matched observation, thus indicating that this source has e.g. been splitted into two, or that it may have been a parasitic source wrongly created in IDT.
This field indicates the number of observations (detection transits) that have been matched to a given Source during the last XM revision.
In particular, matchedObservations = 0 indicates a Source which has been merged to another one by IDU XM, MDB Integrator, etc.
Also, it is proposed to use matchedObservations = -1 to indicate that a given source has never been observed by Gaia (but it was included in the catalog from the IGSL, etc).

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK1
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK2
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK3
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK4
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK1
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK2
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK3
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
