The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK4
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: photGNObs
parameter.description: Number of observations contributing to G photometry
parameter.detailed-description: Number of observations that contributed to the G mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photGMeanFlux
parameter.detailed-description: Mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photGMeanFluxError
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the mean flux in the G-band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photGMeanMag
parameter.detailed-description: Mean magnitude in the G band. This is computed from the G-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpNObs
parameter.description: Number of observations contributing to BP photometry
parameter.detailed-description: Number of observations that contributed to the integrated BP mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpMeanFlux
parameter.detailed-description: Mean flux in the integrated BP band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpMeanFluxError
parameter.description: Error on the integrated BP mean flux
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the mean flux in the integrated BP band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photBpMeanMag
parameter.detailed-description:
Mean magnitude in the integrated BP band. This is computed from the BP-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale.
This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photRpNObs
parameter.description: Number of observations contributing to RP photometry
parameter.detailed-description: Number of observations that contributed to the integrated RP mean flux and mean flux error. This number will be set to 0 if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photRpMeanFlux
parameter.detailed-description: Mean flux in the integrated RP band.

parameter.name: photRpMeanFluxError
parameter.description: Error on the integrated RP mean flux
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the mean flux in the integrated RP band. This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: photRpMeanMag
parameter.detailed-description:
Mean magnitude in the integrated RP band. This is computed from the RP-band mean flux applying the magnitude zero-point in the AB scale.
This number will be set to NaN if no observation for this source was considered suitable for photometric accumulation.

parameter.name: radialVelocity
parameter.detailed-description: Radial Velocity of the object: the radial velocity provided will be the combination of the RV measurements at all epochs (covered by R1). Specifically, it is the spectroscopic radial velocity in the solar baricentric reference frame.

parameter.name: radialVelocityError
parameter.description: Standard error of the Radial Velocity
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{v_r}$ of Radial Velocity of the object at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: radialVelocityConstancyProbability
parameter.description: probability of constancy of radial velocity

parameter.name: photVariableFlag

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Enumerations/GaiaRelease
table.description: Enumeration containing references to the different gaia releases

parameter.name: EPSL
parameter.description: The gaia release containing the EPSL results

table.name: DPC/CU9/ArchiveArchitecture/Enumerations/ReferenceCatalog
table.description: Enumeration listing the possible catalogs used to crossmatch the values and produce validation results.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: fieldEpc
parameter.detailed-description: The identity of the ecliptic-pole field, for convenience, either 'N' (north pole), or 'S' (south pole).

parameter.name: idEpc
parameter.detailed-description: A straight, ad-hoc running source number.

parameter.name: refEpochDouble
parameter.detailed-description: The reference epoch to which the astrometric source parameters are referred, expressed as a Julian Year in TCB.

parameter.name: alpha
parameter.detailed-description: Longitude (Right Ascension) $\alpha$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: alphaError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\alpha$ of longitude (Right Ascension) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: delta
parameter.detailed-description: Latitude (Declination) $\delta$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: deltaError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\delta$ of latitude (Declination) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: sourcePosition
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where this data point comes from, directly from a catalog or via some transformation. Own data (which will be the bulk of the data) will be marked by "0"

parameter.name: varPi
parameter.detailed-description: Absolute stellar parallax $\varpi$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: varPiError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\varpi$ of absolute stellar parallax at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: sourcevarPi
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where this data point comes from, directly from a catalog or via some transformation.

parameter.name: muAlpha
parameter.description: Proper motion component in alpha direction
parameter.detailed-description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}: $\mu_{\alpha*}$

parameter.name: muAlphaError
parameter.description: Standard error of muAlpha in alpha direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\alpha*}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: muDelta
parameter.description: Proper motion component in delta direction
parameter.detailed-description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}: $\mu_{\delta}$

parameter.name: muDeltaError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\delta}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpochDouble}

parameter.name: sourceMu
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where this data point comes from, directly from a catalog or via some transformation. Own data (which will be the bulk of the data in this category( will be marked by "0".

parameter.name: astrmFlag
parameter.detailed-description: In the parameter "astrmFlag" all notes and remarks concerning the preceding astrometric parameters (i.e. coordinates, proper motions, parallaxes) will be encoded. These will include notes on problematic sources, such as those affected by saturation, problematic locations on the chip, extended sources, etc. The method of encoding these still has to be determined.

parameter.name: magU
parameter.detailed-description: The $U$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magUError
parameter.detailed-description: The error of the $U$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magUFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This parameter flags any additional information concerning the $U$ magnitude of a given data point. These could be photometric problems (saturation, problematic part of image, extended source, etc.) or other (to be specified) issues. The meothod of encoding still needs to be determined.

parameter.name: magB
parameter.detailed-description: The $B$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magBError
parameter.detailed-description: The error of the $B$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magBFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This parameter flags any additional information concerning the $B$ magnitude of a given data point. These could be photometric problems (saturation, problematic part of image, extended source, etc.) or other (to be specified) issues. The meothod of encoding still needs to be determined.

parameter.name: magV
parameter.detailed-description: The $V$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magVError
parameter.detailed-description: The error of the $V$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magVFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This parameter flags any additional information concerning the $V$ magnitude of a given data point. These could be photometric problems (saturation, problematic part of image, extended source, etc.) or other (to be specified) issues. The meothod of encoding still needs to be determined.

parameter.name: magR
parameter.detailed-description: The $R$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magRError
parameter.detailed-description: The error of the $R$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magRFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This parameter flags any additional information concerning the $R$ magnitude of a given data point. These could be photometric problems (saturation, problematic part of image, extended source, etc.) or other (to be specified) issues. The meothod of encoding still needs to be determined.

parameter.name: magI
parameter.detailed-description: The $I$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magIError
parameter.detailed-description: The error of the $I$ magnitude from own data. Depending on the source (i.e. telescope/instrument/observatory) this will be either Johnson-Cousins derivate or Bessel - the latter also being similar to the Johnson-Cousins system.

parameter.name: magIFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This parameter flags any additional information concerning the $I$ magnitude of a given data point. These could be photometric problems (saturation, problematic part of image, extended source, etc.) or other (to be specified) issues. The meothod of encoding still needs to be determined.

parameter.name: photFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This flas specifies additional information of more general nature, i.e. applying to the complete photometry rather than to one passband. The infomation encoding has to be specified and will be similar to that of the passband flags (fields 22,25,28,31,34).

parameter.name: radVel
parameter.detailed-description: This field contains the heliocentric radial velocity in km/s.

parameter.name: radVelError
parameter.detailed-description: Error of the heliocentric radial velocity in km/s

parameter.name: radVelFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Flag denoting problems or other information connected with this object's radial velocity

parameter.name: effTemp
parameter.detailed-description: This field contains the effective temperature in K.

parameter.name: effTempError
parameter.detailed-description: Error of the effective temperature in K.

parameter.name: effTempFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Flag denoting problems or other information connected with this object's effective temperature

parameter.name: logSurfGrav
parameter.detailed-description: This field contains the surface gravity of the star in log (cgs).

parameter.name: logSurfGravError
parameter.detailed-description: Error of the surface gravity in log (cgs)

parameter.name: logSurfGravFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Flag denoting problems or other information connected with this object's surface gravity.

parameter.name: abundance
parameter.detailed-description: This field contains the metal abundance in dex.

parameter.name: abundanceError
parameter.detailed-description: Error of the metal abundance in dex.

parameter.name: abundanceFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Flag denoting problems or other information connected with this object's metal abundance value.

parameter.name: specFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This flag contains all additional informations concerned with all the spectroscopically derived quantities, i.e. RV, Teff, log g, anf [m/H]. Encoding will be similar to the other flags and does yet have to be determined.

parameter.name: gMagDerived
parameter.description: G magnitude estimated from R and I
parameter.detailed-description: see MA-002

parameter.name: gRvsMagDerived
parameter.description: G_RVS magnitude estimated from R and I
parameter.detailed-description: see MA-002

parameter.name: gBpMagDerived
parameter.description: G_BP magnitude estimated from R and I
parameter.detailed-description: see MA-002

parameter.name: gRpMagDerived
parameter.description: G_RP magnitude estimated from R and I
parameter.detailed-description: see MA-002

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/AuxiliaryData/GBOT/GbotObservations
table.description:
This table records the precise position measurements of Gaia based on the ground based optical observations provided by the commited observatories. This table is based on the official IAU format for optical astrometric observations; However, due to the enhanced precision requirements for Gaia, four additional columns were added. These denote the full precision right ascension and declination as well as their r.m.s. errors.
The only real consumer of this table is the flight dynamics department at the MOC. We entered ESAC CU1 as consumer, because the data will be transferred through the MOC interface task.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: identifier
parameter.detailed-description: This is the target identifyer. For Gaia observations the value is fixed to "Gaia" using the leftmost four characters.

parameter.name: note1
parameter.detailed-description: This is a single character flag variable used for notes, see http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/info/OpticalObs.html

parameter.name: note2
parameter.detailed-description: This is a one character flag variable for remarks, notes, etc. See http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/info/OpticalObs.html

parameter.name: obsDate
parameter.detailed-description: This is the date of the observation given in {\tt YYYY-DDDThh:mm:ss.sssZ} for UTC. The nominal precision is 0.001 sec. The actual accuracy of the time stamp measurement will be lower in most cases (~0.1 sec). The Z at the end indicates that the time is UTC.

parameter.name: obsRA
parameter.detailed-description: This is the right ascension given in decimal degrees {\tt DDD.ddddddd} ranging from 0 to 359.9999999 degrees.

parameter.name: obsDec
parameter.detailed-description: This is the declination of the observation, given in {\tt sDD.ddddddd}, with s depicting the sign. THe range is from -90.0000000 to +90.0000000

parameter.name: objMag
parameter.detailed-description: This is the object's magnitude given by {\tt MM.MMM}. See http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/info/OpticalObs.html. This format allows for a precision of 0.001 mag, but in practice all values will be to a 0.01 mag precision.

parameter.name: passband
parameter.detailed-description: This is the filter or passband against which the object's magnitude (obsMag) was measured. See http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/info/OpticalObs.html.

parameter.name: obsCode
parameter.detailed-description: This is the 3 character IAU observatory code. For locations without code the code "247" is used.

parameter.name: errRA
parameter.detailed-description: This is the r.m.s. error of obsRA2 given in units of $10^{-7}$ degrees$\times cos (DEC)$.

parameter.name: errDec
parameter.detailed-description: This is the r.m.s. error for obsDec2, given in units of $10^{-7}$ degrees.

parameter.name: errCorrel
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation of the errors. The format corresponds to {\tt sC.CCC}. May be left blank if not available.

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/AuxiliaryData/GBOT/GbotTelescopes
table.description:
This table records the precise three-dimensional locations of the observatories contributing to the ground-based optical tracking (GBOT) of Gaia. This table is necessary, because the standard IAU observatory codes list http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/iau/lists/ObsCodes.html generally contains too few decimal digits for the observatories. Each observatory must be requested to provide the three-dimensional location of the telescope to a precision of 10 meters (total 1-sigma error).
The format is made similar to the IAU observatory codes list. The rho cos phi and rho sin phi values are redundant to latitude and altitude, but both representations are given for convenience.
The only real consumer of this table is the flight dynamics department at the MOC. We entered ESAC CU1 as consumer, because the data will be transferred through the MOC interface task.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: obsCode
parameter.detailed-description: This is the 3 character official IAU observatory code. For observations made at locations not in the list the IAU code "247" is assigned.

parameter.name: obsLong
parameter.detailed-description: This is the observatory's longitude. This must be given to the full number of digits. Precision is 1.1m at equator.

parameter.name: obsRhoSinPhi
parameter.detailed-description: This is the linear distance from the equator plane in earth radii. rho is the distance from the earth's centre and phi the latitude. The precision is 6.4 m using all available character spaces.

parameter.name: obsRhoCosPhi
parameter.detailed-description: This is the linear distance from the earth's polar axis. Rho is the distance from the earth's centre, and phi the latitude. The precision is 6.4 m, using all available character spaces.

parameter.name: obsName
parameter.detailed-description: This is the observatory's name.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: Source identifier as defined in GAIA-CD-TN-ARI-BAS-020-01

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: The right ascension at epoch and equinox J2000

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: The declination at epoch and equinox J2000

parameter.name: errorRa
parameter.detailed-description: The mean error in the right ascension at mean epoch

parameter.name: errorDec
parameter.detailed-description: The mean error in the declination at mean epoch

parameter.name: raEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: The mean epoch of the right ascension Julian Year in TCB. Note if there are proper motions the actual position will be at J2000 to have a consistent catalog and this is provided if the user wishes to add new information or find the best position.

parameter.name: decEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: The mean epoch of the declination Julian Year in TCB. Note if there are proper motions the actual position will be at J2000 to have a consistent catalog and this is provided if the user wishes to add new information or find the best position.

parameter.name: sourcePosition
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where the positional information comes from.

parameter.name: pmRa
parameter.description: Proper motion in RA * at catalogue epoch
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in right ascension multiplied by cos(declination).

parameter.name: pmDec
parameter.description: Proper motion in DEC at catalogue epoch
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in declination

parameter.name: errorPmra
parameter.description: Error in Proper motion in RA
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error of proper motion in RA * cos(declination)

parameter.name: errorPmdec
parameter.description: Error in proper motion in DEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error of proper motion in declination

parameter.name: sourceMu
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where this data point comes from.

parameter.name: galacticLon
parameter.detailed-description: Galactic Longditude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: galacticLat
parameter.detailed-description: Galactic Latitude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: eclipticLon
parameter.detailed-description: Ecliptic Longditude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: eclipticLat
parameter.detailed-description: Ecliptic Latitude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: magBJ
parameter.detailed-description: The $B_J$ magnitude from the GSC23 when present or estimated from transformations when not present in the GSC23 or too bright to be reliable from GSC23. Very similar to B Johnson.

parameter.name: magBJError
parameter.detailed-description: Error in the $B_J$ magnitude

parameter.name: sourceMagBJ
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this magnitude comes from.

parameter.name: magRF
parameter.detailed-description: The $R_F$ magnitude from the GSC23 when present or estimated from transformations when not present in the GSC23 or too bright to be reliable from GSC23. Very similar to R cousins.

parameter.name: magRFError
parameter.detailed-description: Error in $R_F$

parameter.name: sourceMagRF
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this magnitude comes from.

parameter.name: magG
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated $G$ magnitude based on transformations in livelink document RLS 001

parameter.name: magGError
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated of error on G magnitude

parameter.name: sourceMagG
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes which transformation used.

parameter.name: magGrvs
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated $G_rvs$ magnitude based on transformations in livelink document RLS 004

parameter.name: magGrvsError
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated of error on $G_rvs$ magnitude

parameter.name: sourceMagGrvs
parameter.detailed-description: Code in SourceCatalogIDs that describes where base magnitudes came from

parameter.name: classification
parameter.detailed-description: Classification, simply a 0=star and 1=nonstar taken from different sources as given in the souceClass field

parameter.name: sourceClassification
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this datapoint comes from.

parameter.name: toggleASC
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is to be used for the Atittude Star Catalog.

parameter.name: auxGSC23
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the GSC2.3 cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the GSC2.3 id is in the SourceCatalogIDs as idGSC23.

parameter.name: auxSDSS
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the SDSS cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idSDSS

parameter.name: auxUCAC
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the UCAC cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the iSourceCatalogIDs as idUCAC.

parameter.name: auxLQRF
parameter.description: Present in the LQRF QSO aux catalog
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the CU3 QSO Aux cat GIQC, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idLQRF.

parameter.name: auxTYCHO
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in theTYCHO2 cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idTYCHO

parameter.name: auxHIP
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the Hipparcos catalog, 0=no, 1=yes=true.

parameter.name: auxPPMXL
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the PPMXL cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idPPMXL

parameter.name: auxOGLE
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the OGLE cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idOGLE

parameter.name: auxTMASS
parameter.description: Present in the Two MASS PSC catalog
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the Two-MASS cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idTMASS.

parameter.name: auxEPC
parameter.description: Present in the Ecliptic Poles Catalog
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the EPC, false=no, true=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReference table. If yes, the number in the SourceCatalogIDs table is the number in EPC.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: idGSC23
parameter.detailed-description: These are the IDs as published in the various input catalogs converted to a big integer. For the GSC23 we have had to alter slightly the name,specifically: GSC2.3 objects have original names that are combination of region names and running number, e.g. S00000001 is the first object in the region S0000000, we have converted the region names to the ``official'' numerical values in the htm level 6 structure, hence the smallest is S0000000 = 32768 and N3333333 = 65535 is the highest.

parameter.name: idSDSS
parameter.detailed-description: These are the IDs as published in the SDSS DR9 in big integer format.

parameter.name: idUCAC
parameter.detailed-description: These are the IDs as published in the UCAC4 specfically a running star ID number.

parameter.name: idLQRF
parameter.detailed-description: These are the running number in the Gaia Initial Quasar Catalog - version 4 - updated September 2011 - GIQC\_4.

parameter.name: idTYCHO
parameter.detailed-description: These are the IDs as published in Tycho2. In TYCHO-2 objects were identified by 3 numbers (TYC1,TYC2 and TYC3) and we have combined these into one complete number given by (TYC1*1000000.0d0)+(TYC2*10.0d0)+(TYC3*1.0d0)

parameter.name: idHIP
parameter.detailed-description: If the source is a Hipparcos star this field contains the Hipparcos number.

parameter.name: idPPMXL
parameter.detailed-description: These are the IDs as published in the PPMXL, the ipix Identifier (Q3C ipix of the USNO-B 1.0 object) converted to a big integer.

parameter.name: idOGLE
parameter.detailed-description: The OGLE ID is given by a combination of \\ A region of sky identifier (RI) equal to 10, 11, 12, 13, 14 corresponding to map names blg, car, cen, lmc, mus.\\ The file running number ( NNN.N) \\ The running number in the file (RN) \\ The ID is defined as: long(string(RI)+string(NNN.N * 10000))+RN.

parameter.name: idTMASS
parameter.detailed-description: The Two Mass provided the names in a IAU standard fashion of 2MASS JHHMMSS.S +DDMMSS.S these were codeified as +HHMMSSSDDMMSSS.

parameter.name: idEPC
parameter.detailed-description: The IDs in the Gaia Ecliptic Pole Catalogue Version (GEPC 3.0) given as IAU standards: JHHMMSS.SS+DDMMSS.S.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: refListID
parameter.detailed-description: This is the code used in the IntialGaiaSourceList and the IgslReferences to indicate the parameter being updated and where the data comes from to update that parameter. In the IntialGaiaSourceList these codes are called sourcePositionID, sourceMuID, sourceMagB\_JID, sourceMagVID, sourceMagR\_FID sourceMagI\_NID and sourceMagGID and vary from 1 for direct data from the GSC23 to 7 for data from TYCHO and from 21 to indicate the magnitude is from an SDSS transform to 28 to indicate that the G magnitude is from a GSC23 transform. All codes are explained in the IgslReferences.

parameter.name: CANDIDATE
parameter.description: Well certified, but generally lacking spectroscopic redshift

parameter.name: OTHER
parameter.description: Less ce rtified, generally indicated as QSOs by automatic photometric schemes

parameter.name: VLBI
parameter.description: VLBI precise astrometry, kept among Ds even if there is no optical image

parameter.name: VSOURCE
parameter.description: V source with precise optical astrometry potentially useful for the GCFR to ICRF future lin

parameter.name: POOR_OBS_HISTORY
parameter.description: poor observational history, for the purpose of this catalog

parameter.name: EMPTY_FIELD
parameter.description: empty field, as far as the images consulted had shown

parameter.name: NON_ASTROMETRIC
parameter.description: on astrometric or modest precision radio astrometry only

parameter.name: UNRELIABLE
parameter.description: unreliable detection or QSO classification, for the purpose of this catalogue

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/AuxiliaryData/InitialQso/QsoSource
table.description:
This is the latest version of the Gaia Initial Catalog (GIQC\_5) prepared by the GWP-S-335-13000 See GAIA-C3-TN-GPA-AA-001-01 for details.
The catalog contains 1,250,006 entries, divided in 3 classes: defining (D - best certified objects, 191,809 entries); candidate (C - well certified, but generally lacking spectroscopic redshift, 52,482 entries); and other (O - less certified, generally indicated as QSOs by automatic photometric schemes, 1,005,715 objects).
The next columns bring flags and classification for the objects Morphological flags - 0 stellar, stranding from it in Gaussian way. The classification is obtained from the Digitized Sky Survey whenever the corresponding image is available at the time of this compilation. When the image is not available, the literature classification has been translated as best as possible
Astrometric variability flags - they are given by the radius of the accretion disk (Vdisk, in uas), and by the external radius of the dust torus (Vtorus, in mas). These radii are calculated from canonical expressions in the recent literature, and account for a relativist angular size correction.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: Source identifier as defined in GAIA-CD-TN-ARI-BAS-020-01 this filed will be populated doing a Xmatch with the IGSL catalogue

parameter.name: alpha
parameter.detailed-description: The right ascension at epoch and equinox J2000

parameter.name: delta
parameter.detailed-description: The declination at epoch and equinox J2000

parameter.name: category
parameter.detailed-description: Quasara category as defined in GAIA-C3-SP-GPA-AA-002-1

parameter.name: magnitude
parameter.detailed-description: R when available, if not V, G, B, or else average of the literature

parameter.name: redShift
parameter.detailed-description: Redshift, best value from literature, but all Defining QSOs are spectroscopic's

parameter.name: bShr
parameter.detailed-description: Sharpness classification from the DSS B plate

parameter.name: bSrn
parameter.detailed-description: Roundness classification from the DSS B plate

parameter.name: bGrn
parameter.detailed-description: Normalness classification from the DSS B plate

parameter.name: rShr
parameter.detailed-description: Sharpness classification from the DSS R plate

parameter.name: rSrn
parameter.detailed-description: Roundness classification from the DSS R plate

parameter.name: rGrn
parameter.detailed-description: Normalness classification from the DSS R plate

parameter.name: iShr
parameter.detailed-description: Sharpness classification from the DSS I plate

parameter.name: iSrn
parameter.detailed-description: Roundness classification from the DSS I plate

parameter.name: iGrn
parameter.detailed-description: Normalness classification from the DSS I plate

parameter.name: vDisk
parameter.detailed-description: Astrometric variability flags - they are given by the radius of the accretion disk (Vdisk, in uas), and by the external radius of the dust torus (Vtorus, in mas). These radii are calculated from canonical expressions in the recent literature, and account for a relativist angular size correction.

parameter.name: vTorus
parameter.detailed-description: Astrometric variability flags - they are given by the radius of the accretion disk (Vdisk, in uas), and by the external radius of the dust torus (Vtorus, in mas). These radii are calculated from canonical expressions in the recent literature, and account for a relativist angular size correction.

parameter.name: classification
parameter.detailed-description: Classification banners - indicate the origin, type, or particular of the astrometric position

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/AuxiliaryData/Spss/SpssConstancyInfo
table.description: This data type contains the result of variability searches on the SPSS on a specific time interval, which corresponds to a set of periods. The goal is to prevent the use of non-constant stars, which are not good SPSS.

parameter.name: searchFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This flag tells if the SPSS was searched for variability yet; it is set to 0 if a constancy monitoring is not needed for this SPSS, 1 if it is needed but not performed yet, 2 if it was performed. There are no null values for this flag.

parameter.name: variabilityFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This flag tells if the star was validated against variability: it is set to 0 if the star was judged constant, 1 if judged variable, and 2 if the response is not clear or not decided yet. There are no null values for this flag.

parameter.name: band
parameter.detailed-description: The passband in which the constancy monitoring was performed, if any; it can be a letter such as B (meaning Johnson B), V (Johnson V) and so on. This field can be null if no monitoring has been performed yet.

parameter.name: amplitude
parameter.detailed-description: The magnitude of the maximum amplitude of the variation (${\rm A}_{\rm max}$, see SMR-004, for more details) if a star is judged variable, or the minimum amplitude tested ($\sigma_{\rm SPSS}$, see SMR-004, for more details) if the star is not variable, or 3 $\sigma_{\rm SPSS}$ if the star is of unclear nature.

parameter.name: amplitudeError
parameter.description: Error on the amplitude of the variability
parameter.detailed-description: $\sigma_{\rm prec}$ as defined in SMR-004, which is the precision on the light-curve itself as obtained by the comparison stars; it is left unset for SPSS that are not tested for variability.

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/AuxiliaryData/Spss/SpssMag
table.description: This data type is designed to hold magnitude information for one photometric band, obtained from ground-based observations by DU13 or from the literature.

parameter.name: mag
parameter.detailed-description: Flux calibrated apparent magnitude of the SPSS in a given passband.

parameter.name: magError
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the magnitude of the SPSS in a given passband.

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/AuxiliaryData/Spss/SpssRefData
table.description:
This data type is used for data produced by DU13 and, after the ingestion (planned for July/August 2013), can almost totally be considered to be read-only, until the next SPSS data release, which will be presumably before the first Gaia data release (launch+22 months, according to WOM-066).
The data is used by the CU5 external calibration process in PhotPipe (FDA-023) and could also be used by the RVS calibration teams (P. Sartoretti, 2012, private communication). The data type contains the SpectroPhotometric Standard Stars (SPSS) literature and ground-based data and related information. This set of reference values should be as complete as possible. This data type will only contain a few hundred objects at most.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: spssId
parameter.detailed-description: Unique identifier for the SPSS established within CU5DU13. It is a number ranging from 0 to 999. There can be no null value for this field.

parameter.name: spssName
parameter.detailed-description: SPSS adopted name within CU5DU13, among the various used in the literature.

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: Source identifier obtained from the cross-match between the SPSS catalogue and the MDB CompleteSource catalogue.

parameter.name: alpha
parameter.detailed-description: Right ascension of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: alphaErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the right ascension of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: delta
parameter.detailed-description: Declination of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: deltaErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the declination of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: epoch
parameter.detailed-description: Indication of the epoch at which the coordinates are given. This can be J2000.0 or B1950.0, we will report all literature coordinates to one of these two.

parameter.name: muAlpha
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion of the SPSS in right ascension from the literature.

parameter.name: muAlphaErr
parameter.description: Error on the proper motion in right ascension
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the SPSS proper motion in right ascension from the literature.

parameter.name: muDelta
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion of the SPSS in declination from the literature.

parameter.name: muDeltaErr
parameter.description: Error on the proper motion in declination
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the SPSS proper motion in declination from the literature.

parameter.name: parallax
parameter.detailed-description: Parallax of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: parallaxErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the parallax of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: radVel
parameter.detailed-description: Heliocentric radial velocity of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: radVelErr
parameter.description: Error on the heliocentric radial velocity
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the heliocentric radial velocity of the SPSS from the literature.

parameter.name: litMagU
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson U magnitude of the SPSS from the literature, with error.

parameter.name: litMagB
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson B magnitude of the SPSS from the literature, with error.

parameter.name: litMagV
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson V magnitude of the SPSS from the literature, with error.

parameter.name: litMagR
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson R magnitude of the SPSS from the literature, with error.

parameter.name: litMagI
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson I magnitude of the SPSS from the literature, with error.

parameter.name: magU
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson U magnitude of the SPSS from CU5DU13, with error.

parameter.name: magB
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson B magnitude of the SPSS from CU5DU13, with error.

parameter.name: magV
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson V magnitude of the SPSS from CU5DU13, with error.

parameter.name: magR
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson R magnitude of the SPSS from CU5DU13, with error.

parameter.name: magI
parameter.detailed-description: Johnson I magnitude of the SPSS from CU5DU13, with error.

parameter.name: spType
parameter.detailed-description: Spectral type of the SPSS, a string containing the letter (O, B, A, F and so on), a sub-class (from 0 to 9), a luminosity class when available (from I to V) and a letter for peculiar types when needed or necessary, with special conventions for special classes (WD, Sd, and so on).

parameter.name: effTemp
parameter.detailed-description: Effective temperature of the SPSS.

parameter.name: effTempErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the effective temperature.

parameter.name: gravity
parameter.detailed-description: Surface gravity of the SPSS.

parameter.name: gravityErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the surface gravity of the SPSS.

parameter.name: feH
parameter.detailed-description: Metallicity, [Fe/H], of the SPSS.

parameter.name: feHErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the metallicity of the SPSS.

parameter.name: eBv
parameter.detailed-description: Reddening of the SPSS.

parameter.name: eBvErr
parameter.detailed-description: Error on the reddening of the SPSS.

parameter.name: specNumSamples
parameter.description: Number of samples in the spectrum
parameter.detailed-description: Number of samples in the spectrum.

parameter.name: wlSamples
parameter.detailed-description: Wavelength table: each element contains the wavelength corresponding to a given sample of the spectrum.

parameter.name: wlErr
parameter.detailed-description: Estimate of the uncertainty in the wavelength scale of the flux table, averaged along the whole wlSamples table.

parameter.name: fluxSamples
parameter.detailed-description: Flux table: each element contains the absolutely calibrated flux of the SPSS corresponding to a given sample in the spectrum. The related wavelength information is obtained from wlSamples. The flux table will be largely oversampled: at least 5 times the resolution of the BP/RP spectra.

parameter.name: fluxSamplesErr
parameter.description: Errors on the flux table values
parameter.detailed-description: Errors associated to the flux table.

parameter.name: shortConstFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Short-term constancy flag for the SPSS. This gives all the information on variability searches and constancy assessment of an SPSS on timescales ranging from a few minutes up to approximately 1–2 hours.

parameter.name: longConstFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Long-term constancy flag for the SPSS. This gives all the information on variability searches and constancy assessment of an SPSS on timescales ranging from a few weeks up to approximately three years.

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/ExternalCatalogues/AllWISEOriginalValid
table.description: AllWISE source catalogue\\ {\bf Reference paper:}\\ Wright et al. 2010, AJ, 140, 1868\\ Mainzer et al. 2011, ApJ, 731, 53\\ {\bf Original catalogue:} \\ http://irsadist.ipac.caltech.edu/wise-allwise/\\ http://wise2.ipac.caltech.edu/docs/release/allwise/expsup/index.html\\

parameter.name: allwiseOid
parameter.detailed-description: Incremental unique numeric identifier (increasing with declination). This is the only field which was not in the original allWISE catalogue, but was added for cross-match purposes.

parameter.name: designation
parameter.detailed-description: Sexagesimal, equatorial position-based source name in the form: hhmmss.ss+ddmmss.s. \\ The full naming convention for AllWISE Source Catalog sources has the form \\ "WISEA Jhhmmss.ss+ddmmss.s," where "WISEA" indicates the source is from the AllWISE Source Catalog, and "J" indicates the position is J2000. The "WISEA" acronym is not listed explicitly in the designation column.

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: J2000 right ascension with respect to the 2MASS PSC reference frame from the non-moving source extraction.\\ The sky coverage depth for sources in the AllWISE Catalog is approximately twice as large in W1 and W2 as it is in W3 and W4. AllWISE combined W1 and W2 Single-exposure images from the WISE 4-Band Cryo, 3-Band Cryo and NEOWISE Post-Cryo survey phases, and W3 and W4 images from the 4-Band Cryo phase only. The additional epoch of W1 and W2 coverage accenuates the weight of those two bands in determining source properties such as position and motion.

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: J2000 declination with respect to the 2MASS PSC reference frame from the non-moving source extraction.\\ The sky coverage depth for sources in the AllWISE Catalog is approximately twice as large in W1 and W2 as it is in W3 and W4. AllWISE combined W1 and W2 Single-exposure images from the WISE 4-Band Cryo, 3-Band Cryo and NEOWISE Post-Cryo survey phases, and W3 and W4 images from the 4-Band Cryo phase only. The additional epoch of W1 and W2 coverage accenuates the weight of those two bands in determining source properties such as position and motion.

parameter.name: raError
parameter.detailed-description: One-sigma uncertainty in right ascension coordinate from the non-moving source extraction.

parameter.name: decError
parameter.detailed-description: One-sigma uncertainty in declination coordinate from the non-moving source extraction.

parameter.name: radecCoError
parameter.detailed-description: The co-sigma (radecCoError) of the equatorial position uncertainties (raError and decError). Unit arcsec. \\ The covariance between the position errors, $C_{\alpha \delta}$ can be derived from the co-sigma by the formula:\\ $C_{\alpha \delta} = radecCoError * |radecError|$.

parameter.name: w1mpro
parameter.detailed-description: W1 magnitude measured with profile-fitting photometry, or the magnitude of the 95\% confidence brightness upper limit if the W1 flux measurement has SNR$<$2. This column is null if the source is nominally detected in W1, but no useful brightness estimate could be made. The corresponding error column is null if the W1 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit. \\ CAUTION: WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w1mproError
parameter.detailed-description: W1 profile-fit photometric measurement uncertainty in mag units. This column is null if the W1 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit or if the source is not measurable.

parameter.name: w2mpro
parameter.detailed-description: W2 magnitude measured with profile-fitting photometry, or the magnitude of the 95\% confidence brightness upper limit if the W2 flux measurement has SNR$<$2. This column is null if the source is nominally detected in W2, but no useful brightness estimate could be made. The corresponding error column is null if the W2 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit. \\ CAUTION: WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w2mproError
parameter.detailed-description: W2 profile-fit photometric measurement uncertainty in mag units. This column is null if the W2 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit or if the source is not measurable.

parameter.name: w3mpro
parameter.detailed-description: W3 magnitude measured with profile-fitting photometry, or the magnitude of the 95\% confidence brightness upper limit if the W3 flux measurement has SNR$<$2. This column is null if the source is nominally detected in W3, but no useful brightness estimate could be made. The corresponding error column is null if the W3 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit. \\ CAUTION: WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w3mproError
parameter.detailed-description: W3 profile-fit photometric measurement uncertainty in mag units. This column is null if the W3 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit or if the source is not measurable.

parameter.name: w4mpro
parameter.detailed-description: W4 magnitude measured with profile-fitting photometry, or the magnitude of the 95\% confidence brightness upper limit if the W4 flux measurement has SNR$<$2. This column is null if the source is nominally detected in W4, but no useful brightness estimate could be made. The corresponding error column is null if the W1 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit. \\ CAUTION: WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w4mproError
parameter.detailed-description: W4 profile-fit photometric measurement uncertainty in mag units. This column is null if the W4 profile-fit magnitude is a 95\% confidence upper limit or if the source is not measurable.

parameter.name: ccFlags
extFlag
varFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Variability flag.\\ The variability flag is a four-character string, one character per band, in which the value for each band is related to the probability that the source flux measured on the individual WISE exposures was not constant with time. \\ The probability is computed for a band only when there are at least six single-exposure measurements available that satisfy minimum quality criteria. \\ A value of "n" in a band indicates insufficient or inadequate data to make a determination of possible variability.\\ Values of "0" through "9" indicate increasing probabilities of variation. Values of "0" through "5" are most likely not variables. \\ Sources with values of "6" and "7" are likely flux variables, but are the most susceptible to false-positive variability.\\ VarFlag values greater than "7" have the highest probability of being true flux variables in a band.\\ CAUTION: Estimation of flux variability is unreliable for sources that are extended (extFlag$>$0), and sources whose measurements are contaminated by image artifacts in a band (ccFlags[band] $!= '0'$).

parameter.name: phQual
w1mjdMean
parameter.detailed-description: The average modified Julian Date (mJD) of the W1 single-exposures covering the source.

parameter.name: w2mjdMean
parameter.detailed-description: The average modified Julian Date (mJD) of the W2 single-exposures covering the source.

parameter.name: w3mjdMean
parameter.detailed-description: The average modified Julian Date (mJD) of the W3 single-exposures covering the source.

parameter.name: w4mjdMean
parameter.detailed-description: The average modified Julian Date (mJD) of the W4 single-exposures covering the source.

parameter.name: w1gmag
parameter.detailed-description: W1 magnitude of source measured in the elliptical aperture.\\ WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w1gmagError
parameter.description: Error on W1 elliptical aperture magnitude
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in the W1 magnitude of source measured in elliptical aperture.\\ CAUTION: A w1gerr value of 9.999 indicates that the measurement uncertainty is very large, or the uncertainty could not be computed. In either case, the w1gmag measurement should be considered highly suspect.

parameter.name: w2gmag
parameter.detailed-description: W2 magnitude of source measured in the elliptical aperture.\\ WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w2gmagError
parameter.description: Error on W2 elliptical aperture magnitude
parameter.detailed-description:
Uncertainty in the W2 magnitude of source measured in elliptical aperture.
CAUTION: A w2gerr value of 9.999 indicates that the measurement uncertainty is very large, or the uncertainty could not be computed. In either case, the w2gmag measurement should be considered highly suspect.

parameter.name: w3gmag
parameter.detailed-description: W3 magnitude of source measured in the elliptical aperture.\\ WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w3gmagError
parameter.description: Error on W3 elliptical aperture magnitude
parameter.detailed-description:
Uncertainty in the W3 magnitude of source measured in elliptical aperture.
CAUTION: A w3gerr value of 9.999 indicates that the measurement uncertainty is very large, or the uncertainty could not be computed. In either case, the w3gmag measurement should be considered highly suspect.

parameter.name: w4gmag
parameter.detailed-description: W4 magnitude of source measured in the elliptical aperture.\\ WISE profile-fit (w?mpro) measurements are optimized for point sources and will systematically underestimate the true flux of resolved objects. If a source entry has extFlag$>$0, you may wish to examine the elliptical aperture photometry which are measured using areas that are scaled from 2MASS XSC morphologies.

parameter.name: w4gmagError
parameter.description: Error on W4 elliptical aperture magnitude
parameter.detailed-description:
Uncertainty in the W4 magnitude of source measured in elliptical aperture.
CAUTION: A w4gError value of 9.999 indicates that the measurement uncertainty is very large, or the uncertainty could not be computed. In either case, the w4gmag measurement should be considered highly suspect.

parameter.name: tmassKey
parameter.detailed-description: 2MASS PSC association. \\ Unique identifier of the closest source in the 2MASS Point Source Catalog (PSC) that falls within 3 arcsec of the non-motion fit position of this WISE source. This is equivalent to the pts\_key in the 2MASS PSC entry. \\ This column is "null" if there is no 2MASS PSC source within 3 arcsec of the WISE source position.

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/ExternalCatalogues/GSC23Original
table.description: GSC 2.3 Catalogue \\ {\bf Reference paper:} Lasker et al. 2008, AJ 136,735\\ {\bf Original catalogue}: R. Smart private communication\\

parameter.name: gsc23Oid
parameter.detailed-description: Incremental unique numeric identifier (increasing with declination). This is the only field which was not in the original GSC2.3 catalogue, but was added for cross-match purposes.

parameter.name: gsc23Identifier
parameter.detailed-description: The GSC2.3 identification is made of 10 characters, the first four representing the level-6 HTM (Hierarchical Triangular Mesh) coded in base 36 (0..9 and A..Z), and the last 6 represent a zero-filled sequence number assigned to each source upon initial detection.

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: J2000 right ascension with respect to the ICRS.

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: J2000 declination with respect to the ICRS.

parameter.name: positionEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: Plate epoch for GSC-II objects. For Tycho-2 objects, for which RA epoch and DEC epoch are different, the RA epoch is given.

parameter.name: raError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in RA*cos(DEC) at position epoch (positionEpoch). These astrometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: deError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in DEC at position epoch (positionEpoch). These astrometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: fpgMag
parameter.detailed-description: Magnitude in Rf photographic band (red).

parameter.name: fpgMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in Rf photographic band (red).\\ These photometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: jpgMag
parameter.detailed-description: Magnitude in Bj photographic band (blue).

parameter.name: jpgMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in Bj photographic band (blue).\\ These photometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: vMag
parameter.detailed-description: Magnitude in V band.\\ This magnitude may include: \begin{itemize} \item photographic V$_12$ or V$_485$ from IIaD plates, \item V$_T$ of Tycho-2 stars, or \item Johnson V from SKY2000 \end{itemize}

parameter.name: vMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in V band.\\ These photometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: npgMag
parameter.detailed-description: Magnitude in In photographic band.

parameter.name: npgMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in In photographic band.\\ These photometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: bMag
parameter.detailed-description: Magnitude in B band.\\ This filter may include: \begin{itemize} \item B$_T$ of Tycho-2 stars, \item Johnson B from SKY2000, or \item photographic O from pOSS-I. \end{itemize}

parameter.name: bMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in B band.\\ These photometric errors are not formal statistical uncertainties but raw and conservative estimates to be used for telescope operations.

parameter.name: classification
parameter.detailed-description: Image classification:\\ 0 = "star", i.e. point-like object\\ 3 = "nonstar", i.e. extended object\\

parameter.name: status
parameter.detailed-description: The status code is a 10-digit field encoding the properties of the catalog object. \\ This flag is 99999900 for a Tycho object and 88888800 for SKY2000 object.\\ \\ \\ \small{ \begin{tabular}{| l | l | l |} \hline \hline digit & explanation & values\\ \hline \hline ........xx & Number of plates on which the object appeared& \\ \hline \hline .......x.. & Centroid type associated with the exported position & 0 = barycenter \\ && 1 = circular gaussian \\ \hline && 2 = elliptical gaussian \\ \hline && 3 = FPA-applied barycenter\\ \hline && 4 = multicircular\\ \hline && 5 = multielliptical\\ \hline && 6 = FPA + circular\\ \hline && 7 = FPA + elliptical\\ \hline \hline ......x... & Quality of exported J magnitude & 0 = not present \\ \hline &&1 = fit\\ \hline &&2 = extrapolated \\ \hline \hline .....x.... & Quality of exported F magnitude & 0 = not present \\ \hline &&1 = fit\\ \hline &&2 = extrapolated\\ \hline \hline ....x..... & Quality of exported V magnitude & 0 = not present \\ \hline && 1 = fit \\ \hline && 2 = extrapolated\\ \hline \hline ...x...... & Classification unanimity & 0 = mixed vote \\ \hline &&1 = unanimous vote \\ \hline &&2 = unanimous defect\\ \hline \hline ..x....... & Classification voters & 0 = several 15um scan \\ \hline &&1 = one 15um scan\\ \hline &&2 = several 25um scan \\ \hline &&3 = one 25um scan\\ \hline \hline .x........ & Processing status & 0 = complete processing on all plates\\ \hline &&1 = object too big ($>$2562 pix) on at least one plate\\ \hline \hline x......... & Deblending & 0 = single object on all plates\\ \hline &&1 = child (deblended) object on at least one plate.\\ \hline \hline \end{tabular} } \\ FPA = Fractional Pixel Allocation)\\

parameter.name: multFlag
parameter.detailed-description: This flag concerns only the Tycho stars (Status=99999900).

table.name: DPC/CU9/Operations/ExternalCatalogues/Hipparcos2OriginalValid
table.description:
Hipparcos-2 Catalogue
{\bf Reference paper:}\\ van Leeuwen F. 2007, A\&A 474, 653
{\bf Original catalogue:} \\ CDS catalogue I/311\\ table Hip2.dat

parameter.name: sn
parameter.detailed-description: Solution type.\\ The solution type is a number 10*d+s consisting of two parts d and s: \begin{itemize} \item{s describes the type of solution adopted:\\ 1 = stochastic solution (dispersion is given in the 'var' column)\\ 3 = VIM solution (additional parameters in file hipvim.dat)\\ 5 = 5-parameter solution} \item{d describes peculiarities, as a combination of values:\\ 0 = single star\\ 1 = double star\\ 2 = variable in the system with amplitude $>$ 0.2mag\\ 4 = astrometry refers to the photocenter\\ 8 = measurements concern the secondary (fainter) in the double system} \end{itemize}

parameter.name: f2
parameter.detailed-description: Goodness of fit.

parameter.name: bvColour
parameter.detailed-description: (B - V) Colour Index.

parameter.name: viColour
parameter.detailed-description: (V - I) Colour index

parameter.name: hipparcos2Oid
parameter.detailed-description: Incremental unique numeric identifier (increasing with declination). This is the only field which was not in the original Hipparcos2 catalogue, but was added for cross-match purposes.

parameter.name: hipIdentifier
parameter.detailed-description: Hipparcos identifier, the format is HIPnnnnnn.

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: J2000 right ascension with respect to the ICRS (epoch 1991.25).\\ Adopted unit is degrees, while original was radians.

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: J2000 declination with respect to the ICRS (epoch 1991.25).\\ Adopted unit is degrees, while original was radians.

parameter.name: raError
parameter.detailed-description: Formal error in RA*cos(DEC) at position epoch=1991.25.

parameter.name: decError
parameter.detailed-description: Reference error in DEC at position epoch=1991.25.

parameter.name: plx
parameter.detailed-description: Absolute stellar parallax.

parameter.name: plxError
parameter.detailed-description: Formal error on parallax.

parameter.name: pmra
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in RA*cos(Dec).\\

parameter.name: pmde
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in Declination.\\

parameter.name: pmraError
parameter.description: formal error in proper motion in RAcosDEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in proper motion in RA*cos(DEC).

parameter.name: pmdeError
parameter.description: formal error in proper motion in DEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in proper motion in DEC.

parameter.name: hpMag
parameter.detailed-description: Magnitude in Hp band.

parameter.name: hpMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Error on mean Hp magnitude.

parameter.detailed-description: J2000 declination with respect to the ICRS, epoch 2000.0.

parameter.description: mean error at mean epoch in RAcosDEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in RA*cos(delta) at mean epoch.

parameter.name: deErrorEpde
parameter.description: mean error at mean epoch in DEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in Dec at mean epoch.

parameter.name: pmra

parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in proper motion in RA*cos(DEC).

parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in proper motion in DEC.

parameter.name: nEpochs
parameter.description: number of epochs used for proper motions
parameter.detailed-description: Number of catalogs (epoch) used for proper motions.\\ May be blank (null) for stars coming from ARIHIP or Tycho-2 via PPMX (i.e. bit\#1 is set in "fl")

parameter.name: epra
parameter.detailed-description: Mean Epoch for RA.

parameter.name: epde
parameter.detailed-description: Mean Epoch for DEC.

parameter.name: b1mag
parameter.detailed-description:
B mag from USNO-B, first epoch. \\
Magnitudes from USNO-B should be used with care, photometric calibration may be severely off for some plates.\\ For objects from PPMX (bit\#1 set in "fl"), these magnitudes have a special meaning:\\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ Column [PPMX] Content \\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ b1mag [Cmag] Catalogue magnitude from source \\ b2mag [Bmag] Johnson B magnitude \\ r1mag [Rmag] calculated Ru (UCAC) magnitude from source \\ r2mag --- (always empty) \\ imag [Vmag] Johnson V magnitude \\

parameter.name: b2mag
parameter.detailed-description:
B mag from USNO-B, second epoch. \\
Magnitudes from USNO-B should be used with care, photometric calibration may be severely off for some plates.\\ For objects from PPMX (bit\#1 set in "fl"), these magnitudes have a special meaning:\\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ Column [PPMX] Content \\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ b1mag [Cmag] Catalogue magnitude from source \\ b2mag [Bmag] Johnson B magnitude \\ r1mag [Rmag] calculated Ru (UCAC) magnitude from source \\ r2mag --- (always empty) \\ imag [Vmag] Johnson V magnitude \\

parameter.name: r1mag
parameter.detailed-description:
R mag from USNO-B, first epoch. \\
Magnitudes from USNO-B should be used with care, photometric calibration may be severely off for some plates.\\ For objects from PPMX (bit\#1 set in "fl"), these magnitudes have a special meaning:\\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ Column [PPMX] Content \\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ b1mag [Cmag] Catalogue magnitude from source \\ b2mag [Bmag] Johnson B magnitude \\ r1mag [Rmag] calculated Ru (UCAC) magnitude from source \\ r2mag --- (always empty) \\ imag [Vmag] Johnson V magnitude \\

parameter.name: r2mag
parameter.detailed-description:
R mag from USNO-B, second epoch. \\
Magnitudes from USNO-B should be used with care, photometric calibration may be severely off for some plates.\\ For objects from PPMX (bit\#1 set in "fl"), these magnitudes have a special meaning:\\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ Column [PPMX] Content \\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ b1mag [Cmag] Catalogue magnitude from source \\ b2mag [Bmag] Johnson B magnitude \\ r1mag [Rmag] calculated Ru (UCAC) magnitude from source \\ r2mag --- (always empty) \\ imag [Vmag] Johnson V magnitude \\

parameter.name: imag
parameter.detailed-description:
I mag from USNO-B. \\
Magnitudes from USNO-B should be used with care, photometric calibration may be severely off for some plates.\\ For objects from PPMX (bit\#1 set in "fl"), these magnitudes have a special meaning:\\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ Column [PPMX] Content \\ ------------------------------------------------------------ \\ b1mag [Cmag] Catalogue magnitude from source \\ b2mag [Bmag] Johnson B magnitude \\ r1mag [Rmag] calculated Ru (UCAC) magnitude from source \\ r2mag --- (always empty) \\ imag [Vmag] Johnson V magnitude \\

parameter.name: flags
parameter.detailed-description: The flag is a bitwise or number ($\Sigma 2^i$) where each bit number (i) has the meaning:\\ \#0 (1) = if set, one of the coordinates had an excessively large chi square.\\ \#1 (2) = Row is from PPMX. These objects are mostly Tycho stars that were masked out of USNO-B. When this bit is set, the USNO magnitudes (b1mag through imag) have special meanings.\\ \#2 (4) = Row is from PPMX and replaces a single row from USNO-B. This is done when the astrometry from PPMX was better (in terms of error estimates) than the astrometry of the corresponding PPMXL object.\\ \#3 (8) = Row replaces multiple USNO-B1.0 objects. When PPMX contains an object that has more than one counterpart in PPMXL, all such counterparts are discarded on the assumption that they should have been matched in USNO-B1.0 or result from erroneous matches. For these rows, bit\#1 is always 1.\\

parameter.description: error at epoch J2000.0 in DEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in DEC at epoch 2000.0 propagated from mean error at mean DEC epoch, using the Hipparcos routine (posprop) which propagates both star positions and positional errors at different epochs.\\ Column was not present in the original catalogue.

parameter.name: decErrorEpde

parameter.description: mean error in proper motion in RAcosDEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in proper motion in RA*cos(DEC). \\ {\bf NB:} errors on proper motions are given in DEG/year, unit not existing in dictionary tool, will be corrected.

parameter.description: mean error in proper motion in DEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error in proper motion in DEC.\\ {\bf NB:} errors on proper motions are given in DEG/year, unit not existing in dictionary tool, will be corrected.

parameter.description: number of epochs used for proper motions
