table.name: DPC/CU9/ScienceEnablingApplications/PhotometricScienceAlerts/Alert
table.description:
Details of one science alert. The alert refers to a specific, Gaia source.
An alert may finish and a source may later trigger other alerts. The source identifier is not a unique key in this table. The alert identifier is a unique key.
Each record in this table is related to at least one record in each of the following tables: AstroClass; Classification; Classifier; LightCurve.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: alertId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique, opaque identifier for this alert.

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: Source identifier, taken from the Gaia catalogue.

parameter.name: obmtStart
parameter.detailed-description: Time at which the alert is deemed to have started. This is typically the reference time of the FoV transit that triggered the alert.

parameter.name: obmtEnd
parameter.detailed-description:
Time at which the alert ended. An alert may be deemed to end if the source is judged to be quiescent; the procedure for making this judgement is not yet well defined, so the end time connected only subjectively with the state of the source.
This field is set to zero while the alert is in progress.

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: Right Ascension of alerting source. This is taken from the Gaia source-catalogue for the current cycle of observation.

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: Declination of alerting source. This is taken from the Gaia source-catalogue for the current cycle of observation.

parameter.name: alertTransitId
parameter.detailed-description: Identifier for the transit that triggered the alert. The identifier is taken verbatim from the IDT transit-data processed to generate the alert.

parameter.name: detector
parameter.detailed-description: AlertPipe operates a set of software modules called detectors that raise alerts based on particular conditions in the light curve of a source. This field isentified the alerting detector by name.

parameter.name: detectionProbability
parameter.detailed-description: The probability that the detection is statistically significant.

parameter.name: detectionAttributes
parameter.detailed-description:
Any additional information about the detection, recorded as key-value pairs. The set of keys is not consistent between detections -- different detectors will record different attributes -- and may not be constant between versions of a given detector.
E.g.: the detector which triggers on `new' sources brightening from below the detection limit may record the number of times that a source crossed a Gaia FoV prior to the alert without being detected.

parameter.name: nFovTransit
parameter.detailed-description:
The number of FoV transits in a light curve of an alerting source. For each FoV transit, the alert is associated with 0..9 G magnitudes sampled from individual, AF CCDs, and these magnitudes form the light curve.
Sources accumulate further FoV transits after an alert is raised. It is currently undefined whether this field counts all the transits or only those leading up to the start of the alert.

parameter.name: classification
parameter.detailed-description: The astrophysical class to which the alerting source was assigned at the time of the alert. The class is denoted by a code refering to the AstroClasses table.

parameter.name: classifier
parameter.detailed-description:
AlertPipe's classification of sources and events is hierarchical. First, a set of classifer modules are run to consider different aspects of the information, and each generates a probability distribution over (a sub-set of) the astrophysical classes. Second, a meta-classifier is run to combine the first-stage classifications into a single probability distribution, and to extract a most-probable class.
Both primary and meta-classifiers are described in the {\it classifiers} table. This field identifies the entry in that table for the meta-classifier that produced the final classification of this alert.

parameter.name: meanFlux
parameter.detailed-description:
Mean G-band flux at the start time of the alert. This is calculated from the CCD fluxes in the AF CCDs for the alerting transit.
The flux is calibrated using the best-available calibrations obtained from PhotPipe.

parameter.name: crossMatch
parameter.detailed-description:
This field lists the sources in external catalogues with which the Gaia source was matched by AlertPipe during the generation of the alert.
The exact format of this field is not yet defined.

parameter.name: retracted
parameter.detailed-description: An alert may be retracted if the IDT data on which is based are retracted, or if an error in the alerts pipeline is discovered after the alert is recorded. In both cases, this flag would be set to true.

table.name: DPC/CU9/ScienceEnablingApplications/PhotometricScienceAlerts/AstroClass
table.description:
Astrophysical classes to which an alerting source may be inferred to belong.
The set of classes is an implicit union of several kinds of classification and a source may well be assigned to multiple classes. E.g., a source may be considered a "light curve with a bump" and also a "dwarf nova". Another source might be a "new source, no previous light curve" and a "supernova" and a "supernova type 1a", with different degrees of certainty.
Record in this table are conserved throughout the mission. Classes may fall out of use as the classifer software evolves, but their records remain in this table. New records may be added to the table, but codes for existing classes are never assigned new meanings.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: name
parameter.detailed-description: Short, descriptive name for the class, e.g. "Dwarf Nova" or "Supernova class 1a".

table.name: DPC/CU9/ScienceEnablingApplications/PhotometricScienceAlerts/Classification
table.description:
Astrophysical classification of an alerting source. Each record holds a probability distribution for one source amongst the possible types listed in the AstroClass table.
There are multiple classifier modules, so any given alert is expected to have more than one classification.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: alertId
parameter.detailed-description: Identifier for the parent alert: a reference to the Alert table.

parameter.name: classifierId
parameter.detailed-description: Identifier for the classifier module that produced this record. This is a reference to a record of the Classifier table.

parameter.name: classification
parameter.detailed-description: The most-likely astrophysical class, expressed as a reference to a record in the AstroClass table.

parameter.name: probabilities
parameter.detailed-description:
Probabilities that the source belongs to particular astrophysical classes, those classes being identified in the AstroClass table.
The distribution is expressed as key-value pairs, keys being codes for records in AstroClasses and values being probabilities. The set of keys is {\it not} identical for all records: each classification may consider a different sub-set of the possible classes.

parameter.name: attributes
parameter.detailed-description:
Any extra information recorded by the classifier, given as key-value pairs. E.g., a spectral classifier might record colour indices for the source.
The keys in this map are arbitrary and need not be consistent between records, even between records from the same classifier.

table.name: DPC/CU9/ScienceEnablingApplications/PhotometricScienceAlerts/Classifier
table.description: Details of classifier modules in the alerts pipeline that suggest astropgysical types for alerting sources.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: classifierId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique identifier for a \{name, version\} tuple for a classifier. These identifiers are unique throughout the mission.

parameter.name: name
parameter.detailed-description: Name of the classifier, identifying the basic algorithm. This name is typically the unqualified name of the Java class implementing the classifier.

parameter.name: version
parameter.detailed-description: Version of the classifier module: a simple, ordinal sequence of versions.

parameter.name: classes
parameter.detailed-description: A list of codes for astrophysical classes that this classifier uses in its output. The codes are references to records in the AstroClass table.

table.name: DPC/CU9/ScienceEnablingApplications/PhotometricScienceAlerts/LightCurve
table.description:
The light curve of an alerting source. Each row records the photometry of one FoV transit, with separate fields for the magnitudes sampled from each AF CCD.
A light curve will be extended after an alert to track the subsequent behaviour of a source.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: time
parameter.detailed-description: The reference time of the FoV transit that gave the magnitude samples in this record.

parameter.name: af1Mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF1 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af2mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF2 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af3mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF3 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af4mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF4 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af5mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF5 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af6mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF6 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af7mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF7 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af8mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF8 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af9mag
parameter.detailed-description: G-magnitude from AF9 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af1MagError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF1 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af2magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF2 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af3magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF3 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af4magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF4 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af5magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF5 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af6magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF6 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af7magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF7 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af8magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF8 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: af9magError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in G-magnitude from AF9 CCD. Set to NaN if no value is available.

parameter.name: averageMag
parameter.detailed-description: Average G-magnitude of the source within the current FoV transit. Calculated from mean of AF-CCD fluxes weighted by the uncertainties on the fluxes.

parameter.name: averageMagError
parameter.detailed-description: Uncertainty in the average magnitude.

parameter.name: magStdDev
parameter.detailed-description: Standard deviation of the magnitudes calculated from flux-samples of AF CCDs within the current FoV transit. High values of this scatter might be used to detect short-period variability.

parameter.name: zeropoint
parameter.detailed-description: The zeropoint used to calculate magnitudes from the current FoV transit.

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: tyc1
parameter.detailed-description: The TYC identifier is constructed from the GSC region number (TYC1), the running number within the region (TYC2) and a component identifier (TYC3) which is normally 1. Some non-GSC running numbers were constructed for the first Tycho Catalogue and for Tycho-2. The reccomended star designation contains a hyphen between TYC numbers, e.g. TYC 1-13-1.

parameter.name: tyc2
parameter.detailed-description: See tyc1 description.

parameter.name: tyc3
parameter.detailed-description: See tyc1 description.

table.name: DPC/CU9/Validation/AuxiliaryData/MPA
table.description: External data being used for a multi parameter analysis of residuals

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: pmRAStar
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in RA*cos(DEC). External and independant value, not the one obtained by Gaia.

parameter.name: pmDE
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in DEC. External and independant value, not the one obtained by Gaia.

parameter.name: distance
parameter.detailed-description: from 2011yCat.6135....0P catalogue (except otherwise indicated)

parameter.name: color
parameter.detailed-description: BT-VT mag

parameter.name: mag
parameter.detailed-description: magnitude (VT except otherwise indicated)

parameter.name: doubleFlag
parameter.detailed-description: from the WDS Fourth Catalog of Interferometric measurements 0 if not known (here) as double, otherwise maximum angular separation with companion in log of milliarcsec This is a maximum separation (system may be unresolved) and the duplicity may or not be real (e.g. spurious star in GSC giving a spurious entry in CCDM then in WDS)

parameter.name: hipTychoFlag
parameter.detailed-description: 1 if star in Hipparcos, 2 if in Tycho, 0 if not

table.name: DPC/CU9/Validation/AuxiliaryData/Simulation
table.description: Simulations made by AGISLab, errors obtained on astrometric parameters

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: alphaStarObsMinusTrue
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\alpha$ of longitude (Right Ascension) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: deltaObsMinusTrue
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\delta$ of latitude (Declination) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: parallaxObsMinusTrue
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\varpi$ of absolute stellar parallax at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: muAlphaStarObsMinusTrue
parameter.description: Simulated error of muAlpha in alpha direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\alpha*}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: muDeltaObsMinusTrue
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\delta}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

table.name: DPC/CU9/Validation/ClusterValidation/AuxDataSource/AuxDataExternal
table.description: Auxiliary Data for tests using clusters. It includes only data from external Catalog.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: muAlpha
parameter.description: Proper motion component in alpha direction
parameter.detailed-description: proper motion in alpha *cos(delta)

parameter.name: muAlphaErr
parameter.detailed-description: error on MuALphaStar

parameter.name: bmagErr
parameter.description: standard error on observed Johnson-Cousins B mag

parameter.name: vmagErr
parameter.description: standard error on observed Johnson-Cousins V mag

parameter.name: rmagErr
parameter.description: standard error on observed Johnson-Cousins R mag

parameter.name: imagErr
parameter.description: standard error on observed Johnson-Cousin I magnitude

parameter.name: vPHASuMagErr
parameter.description: standard error on VPHAS or IPHAS u mag

parameter.name: vPHASgMagErr
parameter.description: standard error on VPHAS or IPHAS g mag

parameter.name: vPHASrMagErr
parameter.description: standard error on VPHAS or IPHAS r mag

parameter.name: vPHASiMagErr
parameter.description: standard error on VPHAS or IPHAS i mag

parameter.name: loggError
parameter.description: Standard error of log surface gravity

parameter.name: zElement
parameter.description: atomic numbers of element with abundances

table.name: DPC/CU9/Validation/ClusterValidation/AuxDataSource/IgslOrig
table.description: IGSL data, mainly Identifier are requested for cross-match with auxiliary data

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: Source identifier as defined in GAIA-CD-TN-ARI-BAS-020-01

parameter.name: alpha
parameter.detailed-description: The right ascension at epoch and equinox J2000

parameter.name: delta
parameter.detailed-description: The declination at epoch and equinox J2000

parameter.name: alphaError
parameter.detailed-description: The mean error in the right ascension at mean epoch

parameter.name: deltaError
parameter.detailed-description: The mean error in the declination at mean epoch

parameter.name: alphaEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: The mean epoch of the right ascension Julian Year in TCB. Note if there are proper motions the actual position will be at J2000 to have a consistent catalog and this is provided if the user wishes to add new information or find the best position.

parameter.name: deltaEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: The mean epoch of the declination Julian Year in TCB. Note if there are proper motions the actual position will be at J2000 to have a consistent catalog and this is provided if the user wishes to add new information or find the best position.

parameter.name: sourcePosition
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where the positional information comes from.

parameter.name: muAlpha
parameter.description: Proper motion in RA * at catalogue epoch
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in right ascension multiplied by cos(declination).

parameter.name: muDelta
parameter.description: Proper motion in DEC at catalogue epoch
parameter.detailed-description: Proper motion in declination

parameter.name: muAlphaError
parameter.description: Error in Proper motion in RA
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error of proper motion in RA * cos(declination)

parameter.name: muDeltaError
parameter.description: Error in proper motion in DEC
parameter.detailed-description: Mean error of proper motion in declination

parameter.name: sourceMu
parameter.detailed-description: The code that appears in the IgslReferences that describes where this data point comes from.

parameter.name: galacticLon
parameter.detailed-description: Galactic Longditude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: galacticLat
parameter.detailed-description: Galactic Latitude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: eclipticLon
parameter.detailed-description: Ecliptic Longditude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: eclipticLat
parameter.detailed-description: Ecliptic Latitude calculated in float to use for indexing

parameter.name: magBJ
parameter.detailed-description: The $B_J$ magnitude from the GSC23 when present or estimated from transformations when not present in the GSC23 or too bright to be reliable from GSC23. Very similar to B Johnson.

parameter.name: magBJError
parameter.detailed-description: Error in the $B_J$ magnitude

parameter.name: sourceMagBJ
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this magnitude comes from.

parameter.name: magRF
parameter.detailed-description: The $R_F$ magnitude from the GSC23 when present or estimated from transformations when not present in the GSC23 or too bright to be reliable from GSC23. Very similar to R cousins.

parameter.name: magRFError
parameter.detailed-description: Error in $R_F$

parameter.name: sourceMagRF
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this magnitude comes from.

parameter.name: magG
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated $G$ magnitude based on transformations in livelink document RLS 001

parameter.name: magGError
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated of error on G magnitude

parameter.name: sourceMagG
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes which transformation used.

parameter.name: magGrvs
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated $G_rvs$ magnitude based on transformations in livelink document RLS 004

parameter.name: magGrvsError
parameter.detailed-description: Estimated of error on $G_rvs$ magnitude

parameter.name: sourceMagGrvs
parameter.detailed-description: Code in SourceCatalogIDs that describes where base magnitudes came from

parameter.name: classification
parameter.detailed-description: Classification, simply a 0=star and 1=nonstar taken from different sources as given in the souceClass field

parameter.name: sourceClassification
parameter.detailed-description: Code in IgslReferences that describes where this datapoint comes from.

parameter.name: toggleASC
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is to be used for the Atittude Star Catalog.

parameter.name: auxGSC23
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the GSC2.3 cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the GSC2.3 id is in the SourceCatalogIDs as idGSC23.

parameter.name: auxSDSS
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the SDSS cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idSDSS

parameter.name: auxUCAC
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the UCAC cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the iSourceCatalogIDs as idUCAC.

parameter.name: auxLQRF
parameter.description: Present in the LQRF QSO aux catalog
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the CU3 QSO Aux cat GIQC, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idLQRF.

parameter.name: auxTYCHO
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in theTYCHO2 cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idTYCHO

parameter.name: auxHIP
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the Hipparcos catalog, 0=no, 1=yes=true.

parameter.name: auxPPMXL
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the PPMXL cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idPPMXL

parameter.name: auxOGLE
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the OGLE cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idOGLE

parameter.name: auxTMASS
parameter.description: Present in the Two MASS PSC catalog
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the Two-MASS cat, 0=no, 1=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReferences table. If yes the ID is in the the SourceCatalogIDs as idTMASS.

parameter.name: auxEPC
parameter.description: Present in the Ecliptic Poles Catalog
parameter.detailed-description: A boolean that indicates if the objects is present in the EPC, false=no, true=yes. Version and catalog details in the SourceCatalogReference table. If yes, the number in the SourceCatalogIDs table is the number in EPC.

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used,...

parameter.name: solutionId
parameter.detailed-description: The data in the MDB will be described by means of a "Solution identifier" parameter. This will be a numeric field attached to each table row that can be used to unequivocally identify the version of all the subsystems that where used in the generation of the data as well as the input data used.Each DPC generating the data will have the freedom to choose the Solution identifier number, but they must ensure that given the Solution identifier they can provide detailed information about the "conditions" used to generate the data: versions of the software, version of the data used...

parameter.name: sourceId
parameter.detailed-description: A unique single numerical identifer of the source - is obtained from CompleteSource

parameter.name: randomIndex
parameter.description: Random index used to select subsets
parameter.detailed-description:
Random index which can be used in order to select smaller subsets of the data that are still representative. This can be useful for validation (testing on 10 different random subsets), visualization (displaying 1% of the data) and exploring the data, without having to load/download all data.
The column should have non-repeating/unique long, preferably without any missing numbers between 0 and N-1 (where N is the numbers of rows).
This column should be just a counter which gets populated in a totatly random way.

parameter.name: refEpoch
parameter.detailed-description: The reference epoch to which the astrometic source parameters are referred to expressed as a Julian Year in TCB.

parameter.name: ra
parameter.detailed-description: Longitude (Right Ascension) $\alpha$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: raError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\alpha *$ of longitude (Right Ascension) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch} times $\cos(\delta)$.

parameter.name: dec
parameter.detailed-description: Latitude (Declination) $\delta$ of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: decError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\delta$ of latitude (Declination) of object in ICRS at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: parallax
parameter.detailed-description: Absolute stellar parallax $\varpi$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: parallaxError
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_\varpi$ of absolute stellar parallax at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: pmra
parameter.description: Proper motion in right ascension direction
parameter.detailed-description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Right Ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\alpha*}$

parameter.name: pmraError
parameter.description: Standard error of proper motion in right ascension direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\alpha*}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing right ascension times $\cos(\delta)$ at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: pmdec
parameter.detailed-description: Projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}: $\mu_{\delta}$

parameter.name: pmdecError
parameter.description: Standard error of proper motion in declination direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error $\sigma_{\mu_{\delta}}$ of projection of proper motion vector in direction of increasing Declination at reference epoch {\tt refEpoch}

parameter.name: pmradial
parameter.detailed-description: The Radial proper motion $\mu_r$ of the source calculated from the {\em spectroscopically} determined radial velocity $v_r$, the parallax $\varpi$, and the value of the astronomical unit as $\mu_r=v_r\varpi/A$ in units of [mas/yr].

parameter.name: pmradialError
parameter.description: Standard error of proper motion in radial direction
parameter.detailed-description: Standard error of $\mu_r$ (in the same units) calculated by the soure update if $\mu_r$ has been solved for. Otherwise the error is calculated in the standard way from the standard errors of $v_r$ and $\varpi$. If the radial velocity is unknown a standard error of 100 km/s will be assumed for the error calculation.

parameter.name: raDecCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and declination
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and declination in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: raParallaxCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and parallax
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and parallax in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: raPmraCorr
parameter.description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion right ascension
parameter.detailed-description: Correlation between right ascension and proper motion right ascension in dimensionless units [-1:+1]

parameter.name: decPmraCorr

parameter.name: astrometricNObsAl
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) AL that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

parameter.name: astrometricNObsAc
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of observations (= CCD transits) in AC that contributed to the astrometric solution of the source. The total number of observations may decrease as outliers are detected so this number refers to the total number of observations minus the number of outliers.

parameter.name: astrometricNOutliersAl
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AL. Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

parameter.name: astrometricNOutliersAc
parameter.detailed-description: Total number of outlier observations (= CCD transits) in AC (second element). Identified outliers were downweighted and did not contribute to the update of the source. An observation was regarded as an outlier if the downweighting factor was $<0.2$.

parameter.name: astrometricGoF
parameter.detailed-description:
$	t f2$ is the `gaussianized chi-square' indicating the goodness-of-fit of the astrometric solution to the accepted data. For good fits, $	t f2$ should approximately follow a normal distribution with zero mean value and unit standard deviation. $	t f2$ values exceeding, say, +3 thus indicate a bad fit to the data. An alternative indicator of bad fits is the $	t excessNoise$ (see below).
The statistic $	t f2$ was computed from the goodness-of-fit statistic $\chi^2$ (see below) and $
u$, the number of degrees of freedom, according to the formula:
${m f2}=(9
u/2)^{1/2} [(\chi^2/
u)^{1/3} + 2 / (9
u) -1]$
This formula is the well-known cube-root transformation of the chi-square variable (E.B. Wilson \& M.M. Hilferty 1931, Proc. National Academy of Science, 17, 684). It is usually quoted to be valid for $
u > 30$, but is in fact useful for much smaller $
u$. The transformation of $(\chi^2,
u)$ to f2 eliminates the inconvenience of having the distribution (and hence the significance levels) depend on the additional variable $
u$, which is generally not the same for different sources.
For a source update with $N$ astrometric parameters (see ${	t paramsSolved}$), $\chi^2$ and $
u$ were computed as
$\chi^2 = {	t chi2}[0] + {	t chi2}[1]$,
$
u = {	t nObs}[0] + {	t nObs}[1] - N$.
The `unit weight error' of the solution is given by $(\chi^2/
u)^{1/2}$, which is expected to be $\simeq 1.0$ for a good solution, but unlike f2 its distribution still depends on $
u$.
In AGIS the source update deals with bad fits (large $	t f2$) by adding $	t excessNoise$ to the formal observation noise. This effectively reduces the unit weight error of the fit to 1.0 and inflates the covariance of the estimated astrometric parameters correspondingly. However, the chi-square values ${	t chi2}[]$ used to calculate $	t f2$ do not take into account the $	t excessNoise$, and $	t f2$ can therefore always be used as a goodness-of-fit indicator of the source solution in AGIS. The excessNoise provides an alternative indicator of bad fits, although it may be 0 for good fits (unit weight error $\le 1$, roughly corresponding to negative $	t f2$). The actual amount of excess noise used in the fit (and covariance calculation) is given by $	t excessNoise$ if ${	t excessNoiseSig}>2$, otherwise it is 0 (even though $	t excessNoise$ may be positive).

parameter.name: astrometricChi2Al
parameter.detailed-description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AL direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

parameter.name: astrometricChi2Ac
parameter.detailed-description:
Astrometric goodness-of-fit ($\chi^2$) in the AC direction.
These $\chi^2$ values were computed for all accepted observations of the source, without taking into account the source $\tt excessNoise$ (if any). They do however take into account the attitude excess noise (if any) of each observation.

parameter.name: astrometricDeltaQ
parameter.detailed-description:
In the HTPM solution $\tt deltaQ$ indicates the discrepancy between the Hipparcos data and the Gaia data when a single model of uniform space motion is fitted to both datasets. A large value of $\tt deltaQ$ could indicate non-linear motion (e.g.\ in a binary).
$\tt deltaQ$ shows how much the $\chi^2$ of the joint solution increases by fitting a single set of five astrometric parameters to the data, rather than two independent sets of five parameter each. See D. Michalik et al. 2014, \emph{Joint astrometric solution of Hipparcos and Gaia: A recipe for the Hundred Thousand Proper Motions project} (submitted to A\&A) for details.

parameter.name: astrometricExcessNoise
parameter.detailed-description:
This is the excess noise $\epsilon_i$ of the source. It measures how much the assumed observational noise in each observation must be (quadratically) increased in order to give $\chi^2=\nu$ in the astrometric solution of the source. A value of 0 signifies that the source is astrometrically well-behaved, i.e.\ that the residuals of the fit statistically agree with the assumed observational noise ($\chi^2\le\nu$).
The significance of $\tt excessNoise$ is given by $\tt excessNoiseSig$. If ${\tt excessNoiseSig}\le 2$ then $\tt excessNoise$ is probably not significant, and the source may be astrometrically well-behaved even if $\tt excessNoise$ is large.
Independent of the given value of $\tt excessNoise$, the `gaussianized chi-square' $\tt f2$ is always calculated using ${\tt excessNoise}=0$.
The excess source noise is further explained in Sects.~3.6 and 5.1.2 of \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

parameter.name: astrometricExcessNoiseSig
parameter.detailed-description: A dimensionless measure ($D$) of the significance of the calculated $\tt excessNoise$ ($\epsilon_i$). A value $D>2$ indicates that the given $\tt excessNoise$ is probably significant.

parameter.name: astrometricParamsSolved
parameter.description: Which parameters have been solved for?
parameter.detailed-description:
The 6 least-significant bits of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ indicate which astrometric parameters have been estimated for this source. A set bit means the parameter was updated, an unset bit means the parameter was not updated. The least-significant bit corresponds to $\alpha$. The table below shows the values of ${\tt paramsSolved}$ for relevant combinations of the parameters.
Each AGIS run starts with a target number $N$ (usually = 5) of astrometric parameters to solve for, with the following mapping:
\begin{tabular}{lccccccc} $N$ & ${\tt paramsSolved}$ & $\alpha$ & $\delta$ & $\varpi$ & $\mu_{\alpha*}$ & $\mu_\delta $ & $\mu_r$ \\\hline 2 & 3 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & & \\ 3 & 7 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & & & \\ 4 & 27 & $\times$ & $\times$ & & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 5 & 31 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & \\ 6 & 63 & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$ & $\times$\\\hline \end{tabular}
For each source, however, an $N$-parameter update could fail (e.g.\ because there is an insufficient number of observations or their temporal distribution does not allow the update) and in this case a fallback option with a smaller value of $N$ is attempted.

parameter.name: astrometricRankDefect
parameter.detailed-description: The rank defect of the astrometric solution of the source. This should normally be zero, signaling that the rank of the least-squares system for the solution equals the number of estimated parameters (the binary digit sum of ${\tt paramsSolved}$). A positive value means that the astrometric solution of the source is most likely wrong.

parameter.name: astrometricPrimaryFlag
parameter.detailed-description: Flag indicating if this source was used as a primary source ($\tt true$) or secondary source ($\tt false$). Only primary sources contribute to the estimation of attitude, calibration, and global parameters. The estimation of source parameters is otherwise done in exactly the same way for primary and secondary sources.

parameter.name: astrometricRelegationFactor
parameter.detailed-description: Relegation factor of the source calculated as per Eq.~(118) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain} used for the primary selection process.

parameter.name: astrometricWeightAl
parameter.description: Mean astrometric weight of the source
parameter.detailed-description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the ALdirection.
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

parameter.name: astrometricWeightAc
parameter.description: Mean astrometric weight of the source
parameter.detailed-description:
mean astrometric weight of the source in the AC direction
The mean astrometric weight of the source is calculated as per Eq.~(119) in \cite{Ana:AgisMain}.

parameter.name: astrometricPriorsUsed
parameter.description: Type of prior used in in the astrometric solution
parameter.detailed-description: Type of prior used in the astrometric solution: \begin{itemize} \item 0: No prior used \item 1: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion \item 2: Galaxy Bayesian Prior for parallax and proper motion relaxed by factor 10 \item 3: Hipparcos prior for position \item 4: Hipparcos prior for position and proper motion \item 5: Tycho2 prior for position \item 6: Quasar prior for proper motion \end{itemize}

parameter.name: matchedObservations
parameter.description: Amount of observations matched to this source
parameter.detailed-description:
A given source will never be removed from the MDB catalog. Instead, it may simply be left without any matched observation, thus indicating that this source has e.g. been splitted into two, or that it may have been a parasitic source wrongly created in IDT.
This field indicates the number of observations (detection transits) that have been matched to a given Source during the last XM revision.
In particular, matchedObservations = 0 indicates a Source which has been merged to another one by IDU XM, MDB Integrator, etc.
Also, it is proposed to use matchedObservations = -1 to indicate that a given source has never been observed by Gaia (but it was included in the catalog from the IGSL, etc).

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK1
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK2
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK3
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionStrengthK4
parameter.description: Degree of concentration of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionStrength[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is the absolute value of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
The scanDirectionStrength is a number between 0 and 1, where 0 means that the scan directions are well spread out in different directions, while 1 mean sthat they are concentrated in a single direction (given by scanAngleMean).
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionStrength[0] is the degree of concentration when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionStrength[1] is the degree of concentration without regard to the sense of direction. A large value of scanDirectionStrength[3] indicates that the scans are concentrated in two nearly orthogonal directions.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK1
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK2
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
scanDirectionMean[$k-1$] is an angle between $-180^\circ/k$ and $+180^\circ/k$, giving the mean position angle of the scans at order $k$.
The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK3
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.

The different orders $k$ are statistics of the scan directions modulo $360^\circ/k$. For example, at first order ($k=1$), $\theta=10^\circ$ and $\theta=190^\circ$ count as different directions, but at second order ($k=2$) they are the same. Thus, scanDirectionMean[0] is the mean direction when the sense of direction is taken into account, while scanDirectionMean[1] is the mean direction without regard to the sense of the direction. For example, scanDirectionMean[0] = 0 means that the scans preferentially go towards North, while scanDirectionMean[1] = 0 means that they preferentially go in the North-South direction, and scanDirectionMean[4] = 0 that they preferentially go either in the North-South or in the East-West direction.

parameter.name: scanDirectionMeanK4
parameter.description: Mean position angle of scan directions across the source
parameter.detailed-description:
The scanDirectionStrength and scanDirectionMean quantify the distribution of AL scan directions across the source. scanDirectionMean[$k-1$) ($k=1,2,3,4$) is $1/k$ times the argument of the trigonometric moments $m_k=\langle\exp(ik\theta)\rangle$, where $\theta$ is the position angle of the scan and the mean value is taken over the nObs[0] AL observations contributing to the astrometric parameters of the source. $\theta$ is defined in the usual astronomical sense: $\theta=0$ when the FoV is moving towards local North, and $\theta=90^\circ$ towards local East.
